Older adults (50+) are more divided, with 50% supporting and 41% opposing additional scrutiny [1]. Non-whites are also more likely than whites to reject religious-based scrutiny, with 74% of blacks and 66% of Hispanics opposing it compared to 57% of whites [10].

These differences in perception correlate with the importance placed on terrorism as a national issue. Republicans are more likely to cite terrorism, defense issues, and national security as the most important problems facing the nation, with 41% mentioning these issues [4]. In contrast, fewer Democrats (23%) and independents (28%) prioritize these concerns [4]. The increase in concern about terrorism from 1% in December 2014 to 18% in December 2015 further underscores this shift [![{Terrorism became a more prominent concern in 2015}](image5)].

In summary, perceptions of scrutiny of Muslims differ widely across political and demographic lines, with conservative Republicans being more supportive of increased scrutiny and younger adults and non-whites being less supportive. This aligns with the higher prioritization of terrorism as an issue among Republicans compared to other groups.

Perceptions of terrorism and government efforts to combat it have undergone significant changes over time. According to the data, there has been a notable increase in the percentage of Americans citing terrorism as one of the most important problems facing the nation. In December 2015, nearly three-in-ten (29%) Americans mentioned terrorism, national security, or ISIS as critical issues, compared to just 4% a year ago [7]. This shift is also reflected in the survey data from December 2014 to December 2015, where concerns about terrorism increased from 1% to 18%, and defense/national security rose from 2% to 8% ![{Terrorism and related issues saw a significant rise in public concern}](image1).

Americans' ratings of the government's efforts to reduce the terrorist threat have declined sharply. For the first time since the September 2001 attacks, more people now say the government is doing not too well or not at all well (52%) than say it is doing very or fairly well (46%) [3]. This decline is consistent across different demographic groups, with older adults being more critical of the government's performance compared to younger adults. Specifically, 57% of those aged 50 and older rate the government negatively, while only 46% of younger adults (18-29) do so [2]. Additionally, less educated individuals are more likely to give negative ratings compared to those with higher education levels [8].

Political affiliations play a crucial role in shaping these perceptions. Republicans are particularly critical, with only 27% saying the government is doing very or fairly well, down from 63% at the beginning of the year [4]. Independents and Democrats also show decreasing positive ratings, though Democrats remain the most positive group with 64% still rating the government's efforts favorably [4]. The differences in prioritization of terrorism and national security between Republicans and Democrats are stark, as shown in the survey results where Republicans are more likely to prioritize these issues [3].

In summary, perceptions of terrorism and government efforts to combat it have become more negative over time, with older and less educated individuals, as well as Republicans, expressing greater dissatisfaction.

To conclude, perceptions of terrorism and the government's efforts to combat it have become increasingly negative over time, with older, less educated individuals, and Republicans showing more dissatisfaction compared to younger, more educated, and Democratic groups.

According to the survey results, there are significant differences in how Republicans and Democrats view terrorism and economic issues. 

When it comes to terrorism, a higher percentage of Republicans prioritize this issue compared to Democrats. Specifically, 41% of Republicans mention terrorism, defense issues, and national security as top problems, while only 23% of Democrats do so [5]. This difference is also reflected in the image data, where the prioritization of terrorism/ISIS/national security by Republicans is significantly higher than that of Democrats `![{Republicans prioritize terrorism more than Democrats}](image1)`.

Regarding economic issues, the focus has shifted over time. In the period from December 2014 to December 2015, the concern for economic issues among the general public decreased from 34% to 23%. However, this trend does not break down the partisan divide. The image data shows that while economic issues were initially a major concern, they have seen a decline in emphasis over the year `![{Economic issues have become less prioritized overall}](image4)`. Despite this overall trend, the text suggests that Republicans and Democrats may still differ in their prioritization of economic concerns relative to other issues like terrorism and national security.

In summary, Republicans are more likely to prioritize terrorism and national security issues over economic concerns compared to Democrats.

The perception of terrorism as a critical issue varies significantly among different political affiliations. According to the data, four-in-ten (41%) Republicans mention terrorism, defense issues, and national security or ISIS as the most important problems facing the nation, while fewer independents (28%) and Democrats (23%) cite these issues [6]. This indicates that Republicans are more likely to prioritize terrorism compared to other groups.

Furthermore, when it comes to evaluating the government's efforts in combating terrorism, there is a noticeable divide among political affiliations. Democrats are now the only partisan group in which a majority (64%) say the government is doing at least fairly well, down from 85% in January. Independents’ positive ratings have dropped 25 points, from 69% to 44%. And just 27% of Republicans now say the government is doing very or fairly well reducing the terrorist threat, down from 63% at the beginning of the year [4].

This decline in positive ratings across the board suggests a growing dissatisfaction with the government's anti-terrorism policies, particularly among Republicans and Independents. The image further supports this trend by showing survey results on how different demographic groups perceive the performance of certain actions [![{Republicans feel more scrutiny than others based on political affiliation}](image1)]. 

Additionally, the table detailing the importance of various issues to different political affiliations shows that Republicans prioritize terrorism and national security issues much higher than Democrats or Independents [![{Republicans place higher priority on terrorism and national security issues}](image3)]. This aligns with the finding that Republicans are more likely to mention immigration as a significant problem (14%) compared to independents (7%) or Democrats (3%), indicating a broader concern with security-related matters [2].

In summary, Republicans view terrorism as a more pressing issue and are less satisfied with the government's efforts to address it compared to Democrats and Independents.

Independent voters exhibit a mixed set of views on government regulation and economic fairness, differing from both Democrats and Republicans. On the issue of government regulation, independents are nearly evenly split, with 48% believing that government regulation is necessary to protect the public interest and 43% thinking it does more harm than good [1]. This contrasts with Democrats, where 65% see regulation as necessary and only 29% believe it does more harm [1]; ![{Independents are divided on regulation and government size}](image1).

On the other hand, Republicans predominantly view government regulation negatively, with 61% saying it does more harm and only 33% finding it necessary [1].

Regarding economic fairness, 66% of independents believe the U.S. economic system unfairly favors powerful interests, while 30% think it is fair [4]. This aligns more closely with Democrats, where 85% perceive the system as unfair and only 14% as fair [4], but diverges significantly from Republicans, among whom just 29% think the system is unfair and 63% find it fair [4]; ![{Majority of Independents and Democrats feel economic system is unfair}](image4).

In summary, independent voters' views on government regulation and economic fairness tend to be more moderate compared to the more polarized stances of Democrats and Republicans.

Over the past two decades, there has been a noticeable shift in the unfavorable views towards both major U.S. political parties among independents. According to the data, the percentage of people who are favorable to one party and unfavorable to the other increased from 57% in 1994 to 66% by 2018 [image1]. Simultaneously, the percentage of people who are unfavorable to both parties rose from 6% in 1994 to 12% by 2018 [image1].

This trend is further supported by specific statistics on independents' views. In 2018, 28% of all independents held unfavorable views of both parties [image3], reflecting an increase from earlier years. Notably, the share of independents who view both parties unfavorably has declined in recent years, with more than a third (36%) viewing both parties unfavorably at one point in 2015 [9].

When examining subgroups within independents, differences emerge:
- Independents who do not lean toward a party are most likely to have an unfavorable opinion of both parties (37%) [image3].
- Republican-leaning independents are almost as likely as those who identify with the Republican Party to view the Democratic Party negatively (81% unfavorable) [3].
- Democratic-leaning independents also show strong unfavorable views of the GOP, with 84% viewing it unfavorably [3].

The line graph specifically highlights these trends over time for different groups [image4]. For instance, the unfavorable view of the Republican Party among Democrats increased from 59% in 1994 to 88% in 2018, while among Democratic leaners it went from about 48% to 84%. Similarly, the unfavorable view of the Democratic Party among Republicans rose from 77% in 1994 to 87% in 2018, and among Republican leaners from around 64% to 81%.

In conclusion, unfavorable views towards both major U.S. political parties have generally increased over time among independents, with significant variations among subgroups. Independents who do not lean toward a party are particularly likely to hold unfavorable views of both parties. ![Unfavorable views of both parties have increased over time among independents](image1).

The unfavorable views toward the opposing party have significantly increased over time for different political affiliations. According to the data, starting from 1994 to 2018, the percentage of Democrats with a very unfavorable opinion of the Republican Party has more than quadrupled, going from 8% to 37% [2]. Similarly, the share of Republican leaners who view the Democratic Party unfavorably has risen from 64% in 1994 to 81% in 2018 ![{Unfavorable views of the Democratic Party among Lean Republicans have increased significantly over the years}](image4).

For independents who lean towards either party, there is also a notable increase in unfavorable opinions. The graph shows that unfavorable views among all independents toward both parties have fluctuated but generally trended upwards, reaching 56% for the Republican Party and 52% for the Democratic Party by 2018 ![{Unfavorable views among Independents toward both parties have increased over time}](image4).

Currently, the levels of favorability and unfavorability among independents toward both parties are as follows: 
- 28% of independents have an unfavorable opinion of both parties [4], which aligns with the visual data showing that 28% of independents hold unfavorable views of both parties ![{28% of independents have an unfavorable opinion of both parties}](image1).
- Among those who do not lean to a party, 37% view both parties unfavorably [10], consistent with the graphical representation ![{37% of independents without a lean view both parties unfavorably}](image1).

In summary, unfavorable views toward the opposing party have surged over the past two decades, reflecting increasing polarization among partisans and leaning independents, while a significant portion of non-leaning independents also hold unfavorable views of both parties.

The perceptions of Republicans and Democrats regarding China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak and its impact on U.S.-China relations show significant differences. According to the survey results, a higher percentage of Republicans criticize China's response compared to Democrats. Specifically, 82% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents perceive China's handling as "Bad," while only 54% of Democrats and Democratic leaners share this view [10]. This trend is also reflected in the image data, where the bar chart shows that 82% of Republicans/Leaning Republicans (Rep/Lean Rep) view China's handling negatively, compared to 54% of Democrats/Leaning Democrats (Dem/Lean Dem) `![{82% of Republicans vs 54% of Democrats view China's handling as bad}](image1)`.

Furthermore, the criticism extends to the Chinese government’s initial handling of the coronavirus outbreak in Wuhan. A substantial portion of respondents believe this handling contributed significantly to the global spread of the virus. The line graph indicates that over time, the negative perception has increased more sharply among Republicans than Democrats, with Republicans reaching 83% in 2020 compared to Democrats at 68% `![{Republicans' negative views have increased more sharply over time}](image3)`.

When it comes to holding China responsible for its role in the outbreak, Republicans are about twice as likely as Democrats to prioritize accountability even if it means worsening economic relations. The survey finds that 71% of Republicans support holding China accountable, while only 37% of Democrats agree with this stance [9]. This difference is visually represented in the bar and pie charts, which show a clear divide in opinions between prioritizing strong U.S.-China relations or holding China responsible for its actions `![{Majority of Republicans favor holding China accountable, while Democrats prefer maintaining relations}](image5)`.

In summary, Republicans are significantly more critical of China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak and more inclined to hold China responsible for its role, even at the expense of economic relations, compared to Democrats.

The perceptions of China's handling of COVID-19 significantly differ between Republicans and Democrats. According to the survey data, Republicans are notably more critical of China’s role in the pandemic. Specifically, 71% of Republicans believe that the U.S. should hold China responsible for its role in the outbreak even if it means worsening economic relations, compared to only 37% of Democrats [3]. Furthermore, a higher percentage of Republicans (82%) think that China has done a bad job dealing with the coronavirus, with 61% believing China has done a very bad job, as opposed to 54% and 30% of Democrats, respectively [10].

These differences in perception have also evolved over time. The line graph in image2 illustrates this trend from 2005 to 2020. For Republicans and Republican-leaning independents (Rep/Lean Rep), the percentage who criticize China's actions peaked at 83% in 2020, up from 39% in 2005. Meanwhile, for Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents (Dem/Lean Dem), the percentage increased to 68% in 2020 from 34% in 2005 ![illustrating an increasing but less pronounced trend among Democrats](image2).

Additionally, the bar chart in image4 provides a demographic breakdown of perceptions categorized as "Bad" or "Good." Among Republicans, 82% perceive China's handling of the virus as "Bad," while only 54% of Democrats share this view. This disparity is consistent across age groups, with older Americans being more critical overall [5]. Notably, the increase in negative perceptions of China's handling of the virus is evident when comparing 2019 to 2020. Image3 shows that the perception of China's handling as "Bad" rose from 53% in 2019 to 68% in 2020, reflecting a growing dissatisfaction over this period ![showing a significant rise in negative perceptions](image3).

In conclusion, Republicans are more likely than Democrats to criticize China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic, and these critical views have intensified over time.

Americans hold varied views on China's role in the coronavirus outbreak and U.S.-China relations, with notable differences across political affiliations. Around three-quarters of Americans believe that China's initial handling of the coronavirus outbreak contributed significantly to its global spread [4]. This sentiment is particularly strong among Republicans, with 73% believing China’s early handling contributed a great deal to the virus's spread, compared to only 38% of Democrats who share this view.

The survey data also indicates that half of Americans think the U.S. should hold China responsible for its role in the pandemic, even if it means worsening economic relations [5]. The bar chart from the image shows that 51% of respondents support holding China accountable, while 38% prioritize maintaining strong U.S.-China relations, even if it means overlooking China's role [![{51% say the U.S. should hold China responsible, even if relations worsen}](image1)].

Moreover, opinions on China's handling of the outbreak vary significantly by political leaning. Republicans are more likely than Democrats to perceive China's response as poor, with 82% of Republicans finding fault in China's actions compared to 54% of Democrats [8]. This trend is visually represented in another bar chart, where Republicans overwhelmingly view China's handling as "Bad," while Democrats have a more balanced perspective [![{Republicans/Leaning Republicans are more critical of China's handling}](image3)].

Additionally, there has been a shift in public opinion regarding U.S. policy toward China over the years. A line graph shows that the preference for building a stronger relationship with China has decreased from 62% in 2018 to 51% in 2020, while the inclination to get tougher with China has increased from 35% in 2018 to 46% in 2020 [![{Public opinion trends show a shift towards getting tougher with China}](image4)].

In conclusion, Americans' views on China's role in the coronavirus outbreak and U.S.-China relations differ markedly along political lines, with Republicans generally more critical and supportive of holding China accountable than Democrats.

American perceptions of China's role in handling COVID-19 and broader U.S.-China relations have significantly evolved, marked by increasing blame and a souring view of economic ties. According to the Pew Research Center, 73% of Americans now hold an unfavorable view of China, which has risen sharply since 2018 [5]. This shift is notably influenced by the perception that China mishandled the initial outbreak and subsequent spread of the coronavirus [1].

A significant portion of the American public places substantial blame on the Chinese government for the global spread of the virus. Around 64% of Americans believe that China did a poor job dealing with the coronavirus outbreak [7], while 78% attribute a great deal or fair amount of blame to the Chinese government’s initial handling of the outbreak in Wuhan ![{78% place blame on China's handling of the outbreak}](image5).

This negative sentiment extends to broader U.S.-China relations, where around 68% of Americans view current economic ties as being in bad shape [8]. Despite this, there is a nuanced divide in opinions regarding how the U.S. should proceed with economic policy toward China. While more Americans favor pursuing a strong economic relationship (51%) over getting tough on China (46%), those who see China as economically dominant prioritize building a strong relationship rather than confronting China [2].

Moreover, political affiliation plays a crucial role in shaping these views. Republicans are more likely to hold China responsible for its role in the pandemic at the expense of economic relations compared to Democrats [10]. The chart comparing views by political affiliation highlights this divide, showing Republicans generally holding stronger negative sentiments towards China ![{Republicans show stronger negative sentiments towards China}](image1).

In conclusion, American perceptions of China have deteriorated significantly, particularly concerning its handling of the COVID-19 pandemic and broader economic ties, with a majority placing considerable blame on China for the global spread of the virus.

Negative perceptions of China have significantly increased over time, with notable variations across different age groups and political affiliations. According to the Pew Research Center, unfavorable views of China have reached historic highs in recent years [2]. This trend is particularly pronounced among older Americans, as 81% of those aged 50 and older now hold an unfavorable view of China, compared to 71% for those aged 30-49 and 56% for those under 30 [3].

The data from a line graph also supports this trend, showing that the "50 and older" group's unfavorable views have risen sharply from 34% in 2005 to 81% in 2020 ![{Unfavorable views of China have significantly increased among older Americans over the past 15 years}](image3). Similarly, younger age groups have also seen increases, but not as dramatically.

Furthermore, there is a clear partisan divide in these perceptions. Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are more likely to have unfavorable views of China than Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents [6]. The bar chart illustrates this divide, with 83% of Republicans/Lean Republicans holding unfavorable views compared to 68% of Democrats/Lean Democrats ![{Republicans are more likely to have unfavorable views of China compared to Democrats}](image4).

Additionally, the increase in negative perceptions has accelerated in recent months. Since March, negative views of China have increased by 7 percentage points overall [5], with older Americans becoming even more negative toward China [10]. The bar chart also reflects this recent intensification, showing that 73% of the total population perceives something related to China as "Bad," with even higher percentages among older adults and Republicans ![{A significant portion of the population, especially older adults and Republicans, perceive aspects of China negatively}](image1).

In conclusion, negative perceptions of China have become more widespread and intense over time, with older Americans and Republicans demonstrating particularly strong disapproval.

Unfavorable views of China have significantly increased over time among various age groups and political affiliations in the United States. According to the data from Pew Research Center, unfavorable views have reached historic highs, with around 73% of Americans holding an unfavorable view of China [2]. This trend is also reflected in a line graph that tracks changes from 2005 to 2020 for Republicans/Lean Republicans and Democrats/Lean Democrats ![{Unfavorable views of China have sharply increased for both Republicans and Democrats since 2005}](image1).

Among different age groups, the increase in unfavorable views has been notable as well. A line graph shows that the "18-29" group (blue line) increased from 26% in 2005 to 56% in 2020, the "30-49" group (gray line) rose from 41% to 67%, and the "50 and older" group (green line) saw a significant rise from 34% to 81% ![{Unfavorable views of China have increased across all age groups, especially among those 50 and older}](image4). 

Specifically, for the total population, 73% have an unfavorable view, while 22% have a favorable view. Among ages 18-29, 56% view unfavorably, and 36% favorably; ages 30-49 show 71% unfavorable and 23% favorable; and for ages 50+, 81% have an unfavorable view and 14% have a favorable view ![{Unfavorable views are more pronounced among older age groups}](image2).

Furthermore, political affiliation plays a role in these views. Republicans/Lean Republicans consistently hold more unfavorable views than Democrats/Lean Democrats, with 83% vs. 68% respectively [7]. The gap between the parties has widened over the past four months, with Republican unfavorable views increasing by 11 percentage points and Democrats by 6 points [3].

In conclusion, unfavorable views of China have evolved over time, showing a consistent increase across all age groups and a notable disparity between Republicans and Democrats.

Views on China exhibit notable differences across age groups and political affiliations, with significant changes over time. 

Among the total population, around three-quarters (73%) have an unfavorable view of China [4], a sentiment that has reached historic highs in recent surveys. This negative perception is particularly pronounced among older Americans. For instance, 81% of those aged 50 and older hold an unfavorable view of China, compared to 71% of those aged 30 to 49 and 56% of those under 30 [6]. This trend is also reflected in a bar chart where 81% of individuals aged 50+ perceive something as "Bad," whereas only 54% of those aged 18-29 share this perception ![{Older adults are more likely to have negative perceptions}](image1).

Political affiliation plays a crucial role in shaping views on China. Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are significantly more likely to hold unfavorable views of China compared to Democrats. Specifically, 83% of Republicans versus 68% of Democrats have an unfavorable opinion [1]. The gap between these two groups has widened over time, with unfavorable views among Republicans increasing by 11 percentage points in just four months, while Democrats' unfavorable views increased by 6 points over the same period [2]. A line graph illustrates this divergence, showing that from 2005 to 2020, unfavorable views among Republicans rose sharply from 39% to 83%, while Democrats' unfavorable views increased from 34% to 68% ![{Republicans' unfavorable views of China have increased more sharply over time compared to Democrats}](image2).

Additionally, the intensity of these views has also grown. The percentage of Republicans who hold a very unfavorable view of China has nearly doubled since spring 2019, reaching 54% [1]. In contrast, 35% of Democrats express a very unfavorable view [1].

Over time, these trends indicate a consistent rise in negative views across all demographic groups, but with stark differences based on age and political affiliation. The data clearly shows that older Americans and Republicans are more likely to hold unfavorable views of China, and these views have intensified in recent years.

In conclusion, views on China differ significantly across age groups and political affiliations, with older adults and Republicans expressing more negative sentiments, and these unfavorable views have increased notably over time.

Negative opinions of China have seen significant changes over time among different age groups and political affiliations in the United States. According to the data from Pew Research Center [4], unfavorable views toward China have risen sharply across all demographics, but with notable variations.

For instance, older Americans have turned more negative toward China in recent months. Specifically, for those aged 50 and older, unfavorable views have increased by 10 percentage points since March, reaching a substantial 81% [5]. This trend is also reflected in the long-term data shown in ![{The graph shows an upward trend in unfavorable views towards China across all age groups from 2005 to 2020}](image3). The "50 and older" group (green line) starts at 34% in 2005 and rises significantly to 81% by 2020. Similarly, the "18-29" group (blue line) has moved from 26% in 2005 to 56% in 2020, indicating a growing negativity even among younger adults.

When it comes to political affiliations, Republicans have consistently held more unfavorable views of China compared to Democrats [6]. In the most recent survey, 83% of Republicans or Republican-leaning independents hold unfavorable views, while this figure stands at 68% for Democrats or Democratic leaners [6]. This partisan gap is further emphasized by the fact that Republicans are much more likely to express a very unfavorable view of China (54%) compared to Democrats (35%) [6].

A visual representation of these trends can be seen in ![{The bar chart illustrates the percentage of people with favorable and unfavorable views across different age groups and political affiliations, highlighting the higher unfavorability among older age groups and Republicans}](image2). For the total population, 73% have an unfavorable view, which aligns with the overall increase in negative perceptions of China [8]. Among Republicans/Leaning Republicans, 83% have an unfavorable view, and among Democrats/Lean Democrats, this number is 68%.

In conclusion, negative opinions of China have significantly increased over time, particularly among older age groups and Republicans.

The perception of China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic has varied significantly across different age groups and political affiliations. According to the data, around three-quarters of Americans believe that the Chinese government’s initial handling of the coronavirus outbreak in Wuhan contributed either a great deal or a fair amount to the global spread of the virus [6]. This sentiment is particularly strong among Republicans, with 73% believing China’s early handling contributed a great deal to its spread, compared to only 38% of Democrats who share this view.

When examining these views by age group, older Americans are notably more critical. For instance, 73% of those aged 50 and older find fault in China’s pandemic response, compared to 59% of those aged 30 to 49 and 54% of those under 30 [9]. Additionally, the unfavorable views of China have increased markedly over time, especially among older age groups. The graph shows that the "50 and older" group (green line) begins at 34 in 2005 and rises significantly to 81 by 2020, indicating a growing negative perception ![{Unfavorable views of China have risen sharply among older Americans}](image2).

Political affiliation also plays a crucial role in shaping these perceptions. Republicans continue to hold more unfavorable views of China than Democrats, with 83% of Republicans having an unfavorable view compared to 68% of Democrats [5]. This trend is visually represented in the bar chart, where Republicans/Leaning Republicans (Rep/Lean Rep) show 82% perceiving China's handling as "Bad," while Democrats/Leaning Democrats (Dem/Lean Dem) show 54% perceiving it as "Bad" ![{Republicans are significantly more critical of China's handling of the pandemic than Democrats}](image3).

Overall, these trends reflect a general increase in unfavorable views of China in recent years, with older age groups and Republicans expressing the most critical opinions. In conclusion, the perception of China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic varies widely based on age and political affiliation, with older individuals and Republicans being particularly critical.

The perceptions of China's handling of COVID-19 exhibit notable differences among various age groups and political affiliations. Older Americans, specifically those aged 50 and older, are more critical of China’s response compared to younger age groups. For instance, 73% of individuals aged 50 and older find fault in China’s handling of the pandemic [1], which aligns with the trend shown in the graph where the "50 and older" group (green line) has a significant increase in unfavorable views over time `![{The "50 and older" group shows a significant rise in unfavorable views from 2005 to 2020}](image1)`.

Furthermore, the bar chart also supports this trend, showing that 81% of the "50+" age group have an unfavorable view of China, while younger groups like "18-29" have lower percentages of unfavorable views `![{81% of the "50+" age group have an unfavorable view, while younger groups have lower percentages}](image2)`.

Politically, Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are significantly more likely than Democrats and Democratic leaners to criticize China’s handling of the coronavirus. Specifically, 82% of Republicans and those leaning Republican perceive China's handling as "Bad," compared to 54% of Democrats and those leaning Democratic `![{82% of Republicans perceive China's handling as "Bad," compared to 54% of Democrats}](image5)`. This partisan divide is further emphasized by the fact that Republicans are about twice as likely as Democrats to think China has done a very bad job [1].

In summary, older Americans and Republicans are notably more critical of China’s handling of the COVID-19 pandemic compared to younger individuals and Democrats.

In the U.S., political affiliation significantly influences preferences for foreign policy partners and desired cooperation levels. Democrats are more likely to favor cooperation with Germany compared to Republicans [4]. This is further illustrated in a bar chart showing that 61% of Americans prefer Germany over Russia, with only 26% preferring Russia [image1]. Additionally, among Democrats, 35% view the UK as their top partner, while 23% favor Canada and 15% favor Mexico [image2]. In contrast, Republicans lean more towards Israel as a partner, with 26% of Republicans favoring Israel compared to just 9% of Democrats [8].

For Germans, the influence of political affiliation on foreign policy preferences is also notable but less dramatic. Supporters of the CDU/CSU, SPD, and Greens all name France as their top or second-most important partner, followed by the U.S. [9]. However, there are differences between East and West Germans. East Germans are nearly twice as likely to prefer close ties with Russia (38%) compared to the U.S. (23%), whereas West Germans are twice as likely to prefer a close relationship with the U.S. (43%) than with Russia (21%) ![East Germans prefer Russia more than the U.S., while West Germans prefer the U.S. more](image6).

Furthermore, the desire for increased cooperation with the U.S. has risen among Germans since 2018, from 47% who wanted to cooperate less to 50% who now want to cooperate more [2]. Yet, Americans are more inclined to seek greater cooperation with Germany, with 69% of Americans wanting this compared to only 50% of Germans [1]. The influence of political alignment is evident in both countries, with Republicans in the U.S. being more favorable towards Russia and East Germans showing stronger support for Russia [5].

In summary, political affiliations in both the U.S. and Germany shape preferences for foreign policy partners and cooperation levels, with Democrats in the U.S. favoring closer ties with Germany and East Germans leaning more towards Russia.

When examining preferences for increased cooperation with Russia and China between Americans and Germans, several key differences emerge. According to the data, Germans are almost twice as likely as Americans to want greater collaboration with Russia [3]. Specifically, 75% of East Germans prefer closer ties with Russia compared to 63% of West Germans [4], while in the U.S., Republicans show a higher preference for cooperation with Russia at 41%, compared to Democrats at 32% [3].

Regarding cooperation with China, the attitudes diverge significantly. The chart in `![{Germans prefer the U.S. over China, while Americans are nearly equally divided}](image2)` illustrates that 50% of Germans prefer a close relationship with the U.S. over China (24%), whereas Americans are almost equally divided, with 41% preferring Germany and 44% preferring China. Younger Americans aged 18 to 29 are more inclined towards a close relationship with China (58%) over Germany (32%) [4].

Political party affiliations also play a role in shaping these preferences. In the U.S., Democrats are more likely to favor cooperation with Germany (66%) compared to Republicans (57%) [2]. Conversely, Republicans are more inclined to prefer closer relations with Russia (31%) than Democrats (21%) [2]. In Germany, supporters of CDU/CSU tend to favor cooperation with the U.S. more than those supporting the Greens or SPD [9] `![{Partisan alignment shows differing levels of support for international cooperation among political parties}](image3)`.

In summary, Germans are more open to increased cooperation with Russia, particularly in East Germany, while American Republicans show a stronger inclination towards Russia compared to Democrats. Preferences for cooperation with China differ markedly, with Germans favoring the U.S. and Americans being more evenly split. Political party affiliations in both countries influence these preferences, with German conservatives and American Republicans generally more supportive of cooperation with Russia and China.

In the U.S., political party preferences significantly influence attitudes towards cooperation with other countries, particularly Russia and China. Republicans are more inclined to favor closer ties with Russia compared to Democrats, with 41% of Republicans supporting increased cooperation versus 32% of Democrats [3]. This partisan divide is also reflected in the preference for relationships with Germany or Russia; two-thirds of Democrats prefer close ties with Germany over Russia, while only 57% of Republicans share this view [5].

Regarding China, younger Americans, regardless of party affiliation, show a greater inclination towards prioritizing relations with China over Germany. For instance, 58% of Americans aged 18 to 29 prioritize a relationship with China compared to 32% who favor Germany [10]. However, older Americans tend to see Germany as more important than China [10].

In Germany, the influence of political party preferences on attitudes towards cooperation with Russia and China also exists but varies by region. East Germans, especially those aligned with the CDU/CSU, express a stronger preference for closer ties with Russia, with nearly four-in-ten preferring close ties with Russia over the U.S. [2]. This is visually supported by the chart showing that East Germans have a higher preference for Russia at 38%, while West Germans prefer the U.S. at 43% ![East Germans prefer Russia more than the U.S., while West Germans prefer the U.S.](image4).

When it comes to China, Germans overall prefer a close relationship with the U.S. over China, with 50% choosing the U.S. compared to 24% for China [6]. This preference is mirrored in the bar chart illustrating that 50% of Germans favor the U.S. over China, while 44% of Americans prefer China over Germany ![Germans prefer the U.S. over China, while Americans are almost equally divided between Germany and China](image5).

In summary, political party preferences in both the U.S. and Germany shape attitudes towards cooperation with Russia and China, with Republicans and East Germans generally more favorable towards Russia, while Democrats and West Germans lean towards stronger ties with the U.S. and less enthusiasm for closer relations with Russia.

In the U.S., there is a noticeable partisan divide regarding cooperation with Russia. Republicans are more inclined to favor increased cooperation with Russia at 41%, compared to Democrats at 32% [2]. This trend aligns with the general observation that conservative Americans tend to view Russia more favorably than their liberal counterparts [9].

Turning to Germany, the influence of political affiliation on attitudes toward Russia is also evident. In the former East Germany, which has historical ties to Russia, there is a significantly higher preference for closer relations with Russia. For instance, 75% of East Germans support greater collaboration with Russia, as opposed to 63% in the former West [2]. Furthermore, among German political parties, supporters of CDU/CSU show more willingness to cooperate with the U.S., whereas those who support the Greens and SPD do not prioritize this relationship as much [3].

The chart comparing political party alignment visually reinforces these differences ![{Partisan differences in approval or support levels between U.S. and German political parties}](image3). Specifically, it shows that Republicans/Lean Republican in the U.S. have a lower percentage (63%) compared to Democrats/Lean Democrat (75%). Similarly, in Germany, the CDU/CSU supporters have a higher percentage (57%) than SPD (47%) and The Greens (45%).

Additionally, the bar chart comparing preferences between regions further highlights regional differences within Germany ![{Regional differences in preferences for the U.S., Russia, or Both among Germans}](image5). In the former East, 38% prefer Russia over the U.S. (23%), while in the former West, only 21% prefer Russia compared to 43% who prefer the U.S.

Therefore, political affiliations in both the U.S. and Germany significantly influence attitudes toward cooperation with Russia, with conservatives generally being more favorable toward Russia than liberals.

Americans and Germans exhibit distinct perspectives on the leading economic power and their international relationships with entities like the EU and China. When asked about the world’s leading economic power, half of Americans name the U.S., while only 24% of Germans agree; conversely, 53% of Germans see China as the leading economic power compared to just 32% of Americans [2]. This divergence in views is also reflected in their attitudes towards international entities.

Germans tend to have a more favorable view of the European Union (EU) than Americans. While roughly seven-in-ten Germans favor the union, only about half of Americans share this sentiment [8]. The image chart further illustrates this divide, showing that 69% of Germans approve of the EU, whereas only 51% of Americans do ![{Germans have a significantly higher approval rating for the EU compared to Americans}](image5).

Regarding China, the approval ratings also differ. Germans are more likely to have a positive view of China than Americans, with 41% of Germans approving compared to 26% of Americans [5]. Additionally, when it comes to cooperation with other countries, nearly seven-in-ten Americans want to cooperate more with Germany, but only half of Germans feel the same way about cooperating with the U.S. [3].

In summary, Americans and Germans have notably different views regarding the leading economic power, with Americans favoring their own country and Germans leaning towards China. Moreover, Germans generally hold more favorable views of the EU and China compared to Americans.

Americans and Germans exhibit notable differences in their views of international organizations and economic powers, which are influenced by various factors such as ideology and historical context. 

Firstly, regarding international organizations, the data shows that Germans tend to view these entities more favorably than Americans [10]. For instance, when it comes to the EU, 70% of Germans have a favorable opinion, compared to only about half of Americans [image1]. This positive sentiment towards the EU is particularly strong among Germans on the left of the ideological spectrum, with a +15 Left-Right difference in Germany [image4]. Additionally, Germans also have higher approval ratings for the UN (65%) compared to Americans (59%), again showing a more favorable German perspective [image1].

In terms of economic powers, there is a stark contrast between American and German perceptions. Half of Americans believe the U.S. is the leading economic power, while only 24% of Germans share this view; conversely, 53% of Germans see China as the top economic power, compared to just 32% of Americans [image2]. This divergence can be attributed to differing national interests and economic ties. Americans might naturally view their own country as economically dominant, whereas Germans may perceive China's growing global influence more acutely.

Historical and regional factors also play a role. East Germans tend to view Russia more favorably (43%) than West Germans (33%), possibly due to historical ties and proximity [5]. Meanwhile, East Germans have less favorable views of the EU (59%) compared to West Germans (71%), reflecting lingering sentiments from the division era ![East Germans prefer Russia more and the EU less compared to West Germans](image5).

These differences highlight how political ideologies and historical backgrounds shape the contrasting perspectives of Americans and Germans on international organizations and economic powers. In summary, Germans generally hold more positive views of international organizations like the EU and UN, and they are more likely to see China as the leading economic power, whereas Americans are more inclined to view their own country as the economic leader.

American and German perceptions on the necessity of military force and defense spending reveal significant differences. About eight-in-ten Americans believe it is sometimes necessary to use military force to maintain order in the world, whereas only about half of Germans agree [4]. This divergence in opinion is also reflected in attitudes towards defense spending. In 2019, half of Americans felt that spending levels among European allies should remain the same, marking a shift from 2017 when 45% felt more resources should be dedicated to national defense [1]. Meanwhile, Germans are divided between increasing or maintaining their current defense budgets [3], with a notable change since 2017 when about half were content with their country’s defense spending [5].

![{The chart shows differing opinions on an unspecified issue where more Americans than Germans believe it "Should" be done}](image1)

Regarding age demographics and views on U.S.-Germany relations, young people in both countries have more positive views compared to older generations. In the U.S., 82% of people aged 18 to 29 view the relationship as good, contrasting with 73% of those aged 65 and older [2]. Similarly, in Germany, 40% of young people see relations with the U.S. as good, compared to just 31% of those aged 65 and older [2]. This trend is visually represented in a chart showing a consistent 9% difference between the youngest (18-29) and oldest (65+) age groups in both countries [image5].

In conclusion, Americans are more likely to support the necessity of military force and have shifted towards maintaining rather than increasing defense spending among allies. Germans are divided on defense spending and less supportive of military force. Younger individuals in both nations have more positive views on U.S.-Germany relations compared to older generations.

Americans and Germans exhibit significant differences in their views on military intervention and defense spending. In the U.S., a substantial majority of Americans believe that it is sometimes necessary to use military force to maintain order in the world, with about eight-in-ten Americans supporting this view [6]. Conversely, only about half of Germans agree with this stance [6]. This divergence in opinion is also reflected in their views on NATO's Article 5 obligations. Six-in-ten Americans support using military force to defend a NATO ally against a potential Russian attack, whereas an equal share of Germans oppose such action [9].

Additionally, opinions on defense spending differ markedly between the two countries. Half of Americans think European allies should maintain their current defense spending levels, marking a shift from 2017 when 45% felt these allies should increase spending [2]. In contrast, Germans are divided on whether they should increase or maintain their national defense budgets [8]. This division is visually represented in a comparative bar chart that shows changing opinions over the years 2017, 2018, and 2019 ![Fewer Americans see a need for European allies to increase national defense spending, but Germans are divided](image4).

Furthermore, ideological differences within each country influence these perspectives. In both nations, those on the ideological right are more likely than those on the left to justify the use of military force [4]. For instance, nine-in-ten American conservatives see military force as necessary, compared to only 65% of liberals. Similarly, nearly six-in-ten German conservatives find military force justifiable, while only about a third of liberals agree [4].

The stark contrast in opinions is also illustrated by a chart showing that 60% of Americans believe a certain unspecified action "Should" be done, while only 34% of Germans share this view ![Americans are more supportive of unspecified actions compared to Germans](image1). 

In summary, Americans are more supportive of military intervention and maintaining current defense spending levels among allies, while Germans are less inclined towards military intervention and are divided on increasing their own defense budgets.

American and German opinions on defense spending have shown distinct trends over the years, with notable partisan differences within each country. In the U.S., opinions have shifted towards maintaining current levels of defense spending among European allies. According to the data, in 2017, 45% of Americans felt that their European allies should dedicate more resources to national defense [5]. However, by 2019, this percentage had dropped, with only 35% supporting an increase, while a majority (50%) favored keeping spending levels the same ![Opinions have shifted towards maintaining spending](image5).

Partisan differences in the U.S. are also evident. Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are more likely to favor increased defense spending in Europe compared to Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents [8]. This is illustrated in a line graph showing a decline in support for increased European defense budgets among Republicans from 62% in 2017 to 48% in 2019 ![Support has declined among Republicans](image2). Meanwhile, Democrats have seen a more modest decline in support.

In Germany, opinions on defense spending have also evolved. The public is divided on whether to increase or maintain current levels of spending, with about four-in-ten taking each view [7]. A comparative bar chart reveals that in 2017, about half of Germans were content with their country’s defense spending, while about a third felt it should be increased. By 2019, 40% supported an increase, while 41% favored keeping it the same ![German opinions have become more balanced](image5).

Partisan gaps are also present in Germany. Supporters of the CDU/CSU are generally in favor of defense spending increases, whereas supporters of the Greens express more skepticism, with only 28% wanting to raise defense spending ![Political party preferences show clear divides](image4). Members of the SPD fall in the middle, with 41% saying Germany should increase defense spending [1].

In conclusion, American opinions have shifted towards maintaining defense spending levels, with significant partisan differences, while German opinions remain divided but have trended slightly more towards increasing spending over the years.

American and German views on national defense spending have undergone notable changes from 2017 to 2019. In the U.S., the share of Americans who believe European allies should increase their defense spending has decreased significantly. Specifically, in 2017, 45% of Americans supported an increase, but this dropped to 35% by 2019 [4]. This shift is also reflected in the comparative bar chart, which shows a steady decline in support for increased spending among Americans from 45% in 2017 to 35% in 2019 ![{Support for increased defense spending among Americans has declined from 45% in 2017 to 35% in 2019}](image1).

In Germany, opinions have evolved as well. Initially, in 2017, only 32% of Germans supported increasing defense spending, with 51% favoring maintaining current levels [10]. However, by 2019, 40% of Germans favored an increase, while 41% preferred to keep spending the same ![{German support for increased defense spending has risen from 32% in 2017 to 40% in 2019}](image1). This indicates a growing acceptance of higher defense budgets among Germans.

Partisan differences are evident in both countries. In the U.S., Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are more likely than Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents to favor increased defense spending in Europe [3]. The line graph illustrates this trend, showing a decline in support among both groups, but with Republicans still maintaining higher support compared to Democrats ![{Republican support for increased defense spending has declined from 62% in 2017 to 48% in 2019, while Democrats' support has slightly decreased from 34% to 28%}](image3).

In Germany, partisan gaps also emerge. Supporters of the CDU/CSU are more inclined to favor defense spending increases, with 51% supporting it [9], while the Greens express skepticism, with only 28% in favor [9]. The SPD falls in between, with 41% supporting an increase ![{CDU/CSU supporters are more likely to favor increased defense spending (51%) compared to SPD (41%) and Greens (28%)}](image5).

To summarize, American views on European allies' defense spending have become less supportive over time, while German views have shifted towards greater acceptance of increased spending. Partisan differences exist, with Republicans in the U.S. and CDU/CSU supporters in Germany being more supportive of higher defense budgets.

In the U.S., opinions on increasing defense spending in Europe are divided along partisan lines. Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are more likely to favor increased defense spending compared to Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents [3]. This trend is visually represented by a line graph showing a decline in support among both Republicans and Democrats from 2017 to 2019 ![{Support for European allies' increased defense spending has declined among both Republicans and Democrats}](image5).

The comparative bar chart illustrates changes in public opinion over three years regarding whether European allies should increase their defense spending. In 2017, 45% of Americans supported an increase, but this percentage dropped to 35% by 2019. Among Germans, support for increasing Germany's defense spending rose from 32% in 2017 to 40% in 2019 ![{Americans' and Germans' opinions on national defense spending have fluctuated over the years}](image1).

In Germany, political affiliations also shape views on defense spending. Supporters of the CDU/CSU are generally in favor of increasing defense spending, with 51% supporting it, while only 28% of Greens agree [5]. This divergence is shown in a horizontal bar chart comparing these political parties ![{CDU/CSU supporters are more inclined towards increasing defense spending compared to Greens}](image3).

Furthermore, younger Germans aged 18 to 29 tend to view U.S. military bases as less important for national security, with 62% considering them not important [6]. This contrasts sharply with older age groups, particularly those 65 and above, where 61% believe the bases are important [6]. The age-related differences are depicted in a bar chart that highlights the varying importance placed on the topic across different age groups ![{Older Germans find U.S. military bases more important for national security than younger Germans}](image4).

Overall, political affiliations significantly influence opinions on increasing defense spending in both the U.S. and Germany, with noticeable shifts observed over time. Support for increased defense spending has decreased among both Republicans and Democrats in the U.S., while in Germany, support has increased slightly despite skepticism from certain political groups.

Political affiliations in the U.S. and Germany influence opinions on increasing defense spending, with support declining among U.S. partisans and rising slightly among Germans over time.

The perception of the importance of U.S. military bases in Germany varies significantly by age, with older Germans more likely to see these bases as important for national security. Specifically, 61% of Germans aged 65 and older believe that U.S. military bases are crucial for Germany’s defense, while roughly six-in-ten (60%) of those aged 18 to 29 think these bases do not contribute to German national security [9]. This trend is visually represented in the data shown `![{Older Germans tend to find U.S. military bases more important than younger Germans}](image5)`.

In contrast, within the U.S., political affiliations play a significant role in shaping views on foreign policy partners and the importance of U.S. military bases in Germany. Republicans and Republican-leaning independents place more emphasis on countries like Israel and the UK as top foreign policy partners compared to Democrats, who prioritize Canada and Mexico alongside the UK [4]. Despite these differences, both Republicans and Democrats view Germany similarly as their fifth most important foreign policy partner [7]. However, there is a notable partisan divide regarding the support for the American military presence in Germany, although overall support remains high among both groups [10].

To summarize, age differences in Germany lead to varying perceptions of the importance of U.S. military bases, with older Germans finding them more significant. In the U.S., political affiliations influence preferences for foreign policy partners but do not significantly alter views on Germany's importance, while there is a consistent bipartisan support for the U.S. military presence in Germany. The age-related differences in Germany highlight a generational shift in security perspectives `![{Older Germans tend to find U.S. military bases more important than younger Germans}](image5)`, whereas in the U.S., political leanings shape foreign policy priorities [4]. 

Age differences in Germany and political affiliations in the U.S. affect perceptions of the importance of U.S. military bases in Germany and foreign policy partners by creating distinct generational and partisan viewpoints.

The views on U.S. global engagement and handling of international issues significantly differ across political affiliations and educational backgrounds. For instance, a majority of Republicans prefer that the U.S. should focus on its own problems rather than helping other nations [5]. This sentiment is particularly strong among conservative Republicans, who are more likely to criticize China's handling of the pandemic compared to Democrats [6].

On the other hand, Democrats tend to be more supportive of U.S. involvement in international issues. About half or more of Democrats believe that the U.S. should assist other countries in dealing with their problems [8], especially liberal Democrats who hold this view more strongly compared to moderate or conservative Democrats.

Educational background also plays a role in shaping these views. Those with higher levels of education are generally more supportive of U.S. involvement in helping other nations. Six-in-ten postgraduates say the U.S. should help other countries deal with their problems, while majorities of those with less education prefer focusing on domestic issues [10]. This trend aligns with the data shown in the bar chart ![{Postgraduates are more supportive of U.S. involvement abroad}](image3).

Furthermore, opinions on how well the U.S. has handled the coronavirus outbreak are divided along party lines. Around three-quarters of Democrats are critical of the U.S.'s response, while similar shares of Republicans praise it [9]. The image further illustrates this divide, showing that Republicans, especially conservatives, are more likely to rate the U.S. response as "Only fair/poor" [image1].

In summary, Republicans, particularly conservatives, prefer focusing on domestic issues and are more critical of China's handling of the pandemic, while Democrats, especially liberals, support greater U.S. involvement in international issues and have mixed views on the U.S.'s handling of the pandemic. Educational attainment also influences these perspectives, with higher education correlating with greater support for international engagement. 

Therefore, views on U.S. global engagement and handling of international issues differ markedly between political affiliations and educational backgrounds, with Republicans favoring a focus on domestic issues and Democrats supporting more international involvement.

Political affiliations and educational backgrounds significantly influence Americans' perceptions of both the U.S. and China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic.

Firstly, regarding the U.S.'s response to the pandemic, there is a stark partisan divide [3]. Around three-quarters of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents are critical of the U.S.'s response (73%), while similar shares of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents praise the country’s handling of the outbreak (71%). This wide gap demonstrates that political affiliation plays a crucial role in shaping opinions about the effectiveness of domestic pandemic management.

Moreover, education also impacts these views [2]. More educated Americans tend to be more critical of the U.S.'s handling of the pandemic. For instance, around two-thirds of those with a postgraduate degree and six-in-ten college graduates believe the U.S. has done a poor job, whereas only about four-in-ten of those with a high school degree or less share this view (43%).

When it comes to China's handling of the pandemic, the data shows that majorities across all educational groups hold negative views [6]. Specifically, nearly two-thirds of Americans say China has not done a good job dealing with the coronavirus outbreak, including 37% who say the country has done a poor job. Notably, older Americans, who tend to have less favorable attitudes toward China, give it the lowest marks; 69% of those ages 65 and older say the country has done a fair or poor job compared with 59% of those under 30 [7].

Additionally, the bar chart in image3 reinforces the impact of political affiliation on perceptions of the U.S.'s handling of the pandemic ![{Older and less educated Americans, along with Republicans, are more likely to rate the U.S. response as "Only fair/poor"}](image3). For example, among Republicans and lean Republicans, 76% rate the U.S. response as "Only fair/poor," with conservatives being even more critical at 80%. In contrast, among Democrats and lean Democrats, 54% rate it as "Only fair/poor."

In summary, political affiliations and educational backgrounds play significant roles in shaping Americans' perceptions of both the U.S. and China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic. Political partisanship creates a wide gap in opinions about the U.S., while education influences the level of criticism, and age affects views on China's performance.

Americans' confidence in Biden's ability to deal effectively with China is notably lower compared to other foreign policy issues, with only 53% expressing confidence [2]. American perceptions of China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic and its respect for personal freedoms reveal distinct views, with a significant majority expressing dissatisfaction in both areas.

This sentiment is shared across various demographics, although Republicans are notably more critical, with 71% seeing China's efforts as inadequate compared to 39% of Democrats [8].

On the issue of personal freedoms, an overwhelming 90% of Americans believe that China does not respect the personal freedoms of its people [6], as illustrated in ![{A vast majority of Americans believe China does not respect personal freedoms}](image1). When it comes to priorities in U.S.-China relations, Americans lean towards promoting human rights over prioritizing economic ties. According to the same image, 70% of respondents believe the U.S. should promote human rights even if it harms economic relations, while only 26% favor prioritizing economic relations at the expense of addressing human rights issues ![{Americans prioritize human rights over economic relations with China}](image1).

In conclusion, Americans predominantly perceive China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic and its respect for personal freedoms negatively, and they believe the U.S. should prioritize human rights in its relations with China.

The perception of balancing human rights and economic relations with China varies significantly among different political affiliations in the U.S. According to a segmented bar chart, a large majority of Americans prioritize human rights over economic ties with China. Specifically, 70% of respondents believe that promoting human rights should be prioritized even if it potentially harms economic relations ![{70% of Americans choose human rights over economic relations}](image4).

This sentiment is particularly strong among Republicans and Republican-leaning independents, where 72% favor getting tougher on China [9]. This opinion is especially prevalent among conservative Republicans, with 81% supporting a tougher stance [9]. The data from a bar chart further illustrates this divide, showing that 61% of white respondents and 72% of Republicans/Lean Republicans prefer getting tougher with China, while only 37% of Democrats/Lean Democrats agree with this approach ![{Republicans lean towards "Getting tougher" while Democrats favor "Building a strong relationship"}](image2).

On the other hand, Democrats tend to favor building stronger economic relationships with China. Among Democrats, 60% support focusing on building a strong relationship rather than getting tougher on trade policies [9]. This preference is more pronounced among liberal Democrats, who are most likely to emphasize human rights over economic dealings in U.S.-China relations [6].

In summary, Republicans, especially conservatives, are more inclined to prioritize human rights and getting tougher with China, while Democrats, particularly liberals, lean towards strengthening economic relations despite concerns about human rights.

The views on promoting human rights over economic relations with China and getting tougher on trade issues vary significantly among different political affiliations in the U.S. According to the data, a substantial majority of Americans prioritize human rights over economic ties with China. Specifically, 70% of Americans choose human rights even if it potentially harms economic relations [7]. This sentiment is consistent across both Republicans and Democrats, with about seven-in-ten from each party supporting this stance [10].

The image further reinforces these findings, showing that while a majority of Republicans support getting tougher on China, Democrats predominantly prefer building a strong relationship ![{Democrats prefer building a strong relationship with China}](image5).

The perspectives on trade policies with China vary significantly across different political affiliations in the U.S. According to the data, Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are more inclined to believe that increased tariffs on Chinese products have been beneficial for the country. In contrast, Democrats and Democrat-leaning independents predominantly perceive the tariffs as detrimental to the U.S., with 60% believing they were bad for the country [5]. In conclusion, political affiliation plays a crucial role in shaping views on trade policies with China and preferences for either getting tougher or building stronger relationships. Republicans predominantly favor tougher policies and view tariffs positively, while Democrats prefer building stronger relationships and generally see tariffs as harmful.

Politically, Republicans are significantly more likely than Democrats to support limitations on Chinese students attending U.S. colleges or universities [1]. Specifically, 69% of Republicans/Leaning Republican support these limitations, compared to just 42% of Democrats/Leaning Democrat [4]. This aligns with the overall higher distrust of Chinese leadership among Republicans; for instance, half of American men, who tend to lean Republican, have no confidence at all in Xi Jinping, particularly those aged 65 and older [10].

The image data reinforces this political divide, showing that Republicans, especially conservatives within this group, are more inclined to see the impact of Chinese students as "Bad for the U.S." with 25% of Republicans/Lean Rep viewing it negatively compared to 60% of Democrats/Lean Dem [image3]. Moreover, the bar chart depicting levels of confidence in Chinese leadership reveals that Republicans/Lean Rep have significantly higher rates of "No confidence at all" in Xi Jinping (50%) compared to Democrats/Lean Dem (only one-third) [image1].

In conclusion, opinions on limiting Chinese students in U.S. universities differ markedly across age and political affiliation, with older and Republican-leaning individuals more supportive of restrictions, which correlates with their lower confidence in Chinese leadership.
