However, by 2016, COD's share decreased to 50%, while other electronic payment methods such as debit cards, EMI payments, and third-party wallets gained prominence [9]. This trend is visually represented in the bar chart showing the distribution of online retail payment methods ![{Shift towards more varied electronic payment methods}](image1).

Furthermore, the increase in digital advertising spend reflects the growing importance of online platforms. From 2012 to 2016, digital advertising grew from INR 20 billion to INR 57 billion, achieving a CAGR of 29.9%. This significant rise underscores the shift in advertising strategies towards digital channels ![{Digital advertising spend increased significantly}](image5).

Social media also played a crucial role in enhancing brand visibility and customer engagement. Politician Narendra Modi’s Facebook profile exemplifies this, showing an increase in followers from 110 million in 2014 to 175 million in 2016. Such platforms serve as powerful tools for reaching a broader audience and promoting eCommerce activities ![{Increase in social media following over years}](image2).

Additionally, the revenue from product eCommerce surged from $3 billion in 2014 to $13 billion in 2018, highlighting the substantial growth in this sector. The travel and other categories also saw a rise, contributing to an overall increase in total revenue from $11 billion to $43 billion over the four-year period ![{Revenue growth in eCommerce and travel sectors}](image4).

In summary, the growth in digital platforms and social media has significantly boosted advertising and eCommerce in India, leading to diversified payment methods, increased digital ad spends, and higher eCommerce revenues.

The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) operates under the Department of Space (DOS), which is overseen by the Space Commission and ultimately by the Prime Minister [7]. The organizational structure within DOS includes ISRO, along with other entities such as Physical Research Laboratory (PRL), National Atmospheric Research Laboratory (NARL), North Eastern-Space Applications Centre (NE-SAC), Semi-Conductor Laboratory (SCL), and Antrix Corporation [3]. These entities are interconnected in a hierarchical manner, as illustrated in the organizational chart [![{Organizational hierarchy within the Department of Space}](image3)](image3).

Antrix Corporation, established in 1992, functions as the commercial arm of ISRO for marketing space products and services [2]. Meanwhile, specialized centers like NARL focus on atmospheric research [5], and NE-SAC supports developmental projects in the North Eastern Region using space technology [6].

Regarding budget allocation, the financial data for the years 2015-2016 and 2016-2017 shows that the largest portion of the budget was allocated to Space Technology. For instance, in 2015-2016, the budget estimate (BE) was 4596.2 crores, revised estimate (RE) was 4351.78 crores, and for 2016-2017, it increased to 5235.68 crores [![{Budgetary allocations across different programs}](image1)](image1). Space Applications also received significant funding, with BEs of 962.32 crores in 2015-2016 and 1034.39 crores in 2016-2017. The INSAT Operational program saw a decrease from 1320.95 crores in BE 2015-2016 to 796.1 crores in BE 2016-2017. Space Sciences and Direction & Administration and Other Programmes had relatively smaller but consistent budgets.

In summary, the organizational structure of ISRO is well-defined within the DOS, and its budget was predominantly allocated to Space Technology and Space Applications for the fiscal years 2015-2016 and 2016-2017.

The Indian Space Programme encompasses a variety of centers, each with specific roles that contribute to the overall advancement of space science and technology in India. Antrix Corporation Limited, established in 1992 as a government-owned company under the Department of Space (DOS), plays a crucial role in promoting and commercially exploiting space products and services developed by ISRO [2]. Antrix provides end-to-end solutions for space products and services to international customers, covering applications like communications, earth observation, and scientific missions [4].

The Indian Institute of Space Science and Technology (IIST) is another significant entity within this framework. Located in Thiruvananthapuram, IIST offers specialized education in space science and technology to meet the demands of the Indian Space Programme [5]. This institution not only educates but also conducts research built on academic programs in aerospace engineering, avionics, and other space-related fields.

National Atmospheric Research Laboratory (NARL), situated at Gadanki near Tirupati, focuses on atmospheric research with an emphasis on developing capabilities to predict the behavior of the Earth’s atmosphere through observations and modeling [9]. NARL's activities span across various groups dedicated to radar application, ionospheric research, cloud systems, and more [8], as illustrated in the image of the MST Radar facility `![{MST Radar facility used for atmospheric research}](image3)`.

Semi-Conductor Laboratory (SCL) in Chandigarh aims to create a strong microelectronics base in the country by focusing on the design, development, fabrication, assembly, testing, and reliability assurance of CMOS and MEMS devices [10]. The cleanroom environment depicted in the image shows the meticulous work involved in semiconductor manufacturing `![{Cleanroom environment for semiconductor fabrication}](image5)`.

The budgetary allocations reflect the importance of these centers. For instance, the bar chart comparing budget estimates from 2015-2016 and 2016-2017 indicates that Space Technology received the highest allocation, emphasizing its critical role in advancing space capabilities `![{Budget allocations highlight the priority of different space programs}](image1)`. Additionally, the organizational chart underscores the structured hierarchy and interconnectedness of these entities within the DOS, ensuring efficient oversight and coordination `![{Organizational structure of the Department of Space}](image2)`.

Furthermore, the map of India highlighting various ISRO facilities demonstrates the geographical spread and specialization of each location, such as the Semi-Conductor Laboratory in Chandigarh and multiple centers in Bengaluru [4]. This strategic distribution ensures comprehensive coverage and support for space-related activities across the nation `![{Map showing locations of ISRO facilities}](image4)`.

In conclusion, the roles and significance of different centers under the Indian Space Programme are clearly defined and supported by substantial budget allocations, reflecting their importance in achieving national and international space objectives.

The National Atmospheric Research Laboratory (NARL) and the Semiconductor Laboratory (SCL) play distinct yet crucial roles within India's space research and technology infrastructure. NARL, located at Gadanki near Tirupati, is an autonomous society supported by the Department of Space (DOS). Its primary function is to conduct atmospheric research with a vision to "Developing capability to predict the behaviour of the earth’s atmosphere through observations and modeling" [4]. To achieve this vision, NARL emphasizes technology development, observations, data archival, dissemination, assimilation, and modeling [4]. The laboratory is equipped with advanced facilities such as the MST Radar facility, which is essential for conducting atmospheric studies [5]. ![MST Radar facility at NARL](image5)

On the other hand, the Semi-Conductor Laboratory (SCL) in Chandigarh focuses on creating a strong microelectronics base in the country and enhancing capabilities in the VLSI domain [8]. SCL's activities revolve around the design, development, fabrication, assembly, testing, and reliability assurance of CMOS and MEMS devices [8]. The laboratory has successfully upgraded its Wafer Fabrication Lab to an $8"$ CMOS Wafer Fabrication Line, which has already processed several production lots with ASICs/IPs/Test Chips designed in-house [9]. This facility supports complex semiconductor manufacturing processes, ensuring high reliability and performance of electronic components used in various space applications [9]. ![Cleanroom environment in SCL](image4)

In summary, NARL's primary function is atmospheric research supported by advanced radar facilities, while SCL specializes in semiconductor technology with state-of-the-art cleanroom and fabrication facilities.

The differences in technology usage within the household compared to outside the household can be highlighted by examining both the availability and frequency of use for various devices. According to the data, a significant number of people do not utilize technologies outside their homes; specifically, 68% do not use any of these technologies outside of home ![{68% do not use any of these outside of home}](image1). Conversely, within households, mobile phones are the most commonly owned device with an overall ownership rate of 86%, while radio ownership stands at 45% [10].

When it comes to radio listening habits, the frequency varies significantly across demographics. Overall, 46% of respondents never listen to the radio, whereas 27% listen every day ![{46% never listened to the radio}](image4). This trend is consistent between rural and urban areas, but there is a notable difference in gender-based habits. Males tend to listen more frequently than females, with 34.3% of males listening every day compared to only 20% of females.

In terms of how people access radio content, the data reveals that 76% of respondents primarily use a radio set, while 40% use a mobile phone ![{76% of respondents listen to the radio via a radio set}](image3). In rural areas, reliance on traditional radio sets is slightly higher, with 77% using a radio set and 39% using a mobile phone. Urban areas show a preference for mobile phones, with 70% using them for radio listening.

Moreover, the disparity in technology access between rural and urban households further influences these habits. For instance, radio ownership is almost equal in rural (45.3%) and urban (46.1%) areas, but internet access is much lower in rural areas (3.1%) compared to urban areas (16.1%) ![{Radio ownership is almost equal in rural and urban areas}](image2).

In summary, while mobile phones are widely used within households, fewer people use them or other technologies outside their homes. Radio listening habits differ notably by gender and location, with males and urban residents showing higher engagement. The primary method of accessing radio content is through traditional radio sets, although mobile phones are increasingly popular, especially in urban areas.

According to the survey data, the frequency of access to newspapers and television can be compared using both textual and visual information.

To understand how the population distribution by caste/ethnicity compares with the distribution by religion and geographic location in Nepal as of September 2014, let's analyze the provided data.

Firstly, the distribution of castes and ethnicities shows a detailed breakdown of various groups within the population. For instance, the Chhetri caste makes up 16.6% of the population overall but accounted for 15.3% in September 2014 [image13]. This indicates slight changes in representation over time, which could be due to migration or other demographic shifts.

In terms of religious composition, Hinduism is the predominant religion with 84.9% adherence in September 2014, followed by Buddhism at 8.2%, Islam at 4.3%, Christianity at 1.2%, Kirat at 1.4%, Atheist at 0.1%, and Others at 0% [image2]. The dominance of Hinduism aligns with the historical and cultural context of Nepal.

Geographically, the population is distributed across different regions: Eastern (21.9%), Central (36.5%), Western (18.7%), Mid-Western (13.3%), and Far-Western (9.6%) [image3]. Additionally, the ecological zones show that the Tarai region has the highest population percentage at 50.2%, followed by the Hill region at 43.1%, and the Mountain region at 6.7% [image4].

The map of Nepal further illustrates the geographical distribution of samples, with districts categorized into Sample Mountain District (red), Sample Hill District (green), Sample Tarai District (yellow), and Sample Kathmandu Valley District (purple) ![Districts are color-coded based on their geographical characteristics and sample representation](image1).

Comparing these distributions, we observe that while the religious composition is heavily skewed towards Hinduism, the caste/ethnic distribution reflects a more diverse makeup with several significant groups such as Chhetri, Brahmin, and others. Geographically, the Tarai region hosts the largest portion of the population, closely followed by the Hill region.

In conclusion, the population distribution by caste/ethnicity is more varied compared to the relatively homogeneous religious distribution dominated by Hinduism. Geographically, the population is concentrated in the Tarai and Hill regions, reflecting both ecological and developmental patterns within Nepal.

The rural-urban distribution of the population remained consistent between the initial period and September 2014, with 83% residing in rural areas and 17% in urban areas, as indicated in the table ![{83% rural, 17% urban}](image3).

From the perspective of caste/ethnicity, there were notable changes over time. The overall distribution shifted slightly among various groups. For instance, the Chhetri caste saw a decrease from 16.6% to 15.3%, while the Brahmin group maintained a relatively stable percentage [12]. Additionally, the Madhesi category, which encompasses several ethnic groups, accounted for 35.3% of the population in September 2014, as shown in the table ![{Non-Madhesi 64.7%, Madhesi 35.3%}](image4).

In summary, while the rural-urban distribution remained unchanged, there were minor shifts in the demographic composition of different castes and ethnicities between the initial period and September 2014.

The relationship between mobile internet usage activities and shopping behaviors in Indonesia can be understood by examining the data provided. According to the graphic on mobile Internet activities, social media engagement stands out as a dominant activity, accounting for 24% of all mobile internet usage [image3]. This aligns with the high penetration of Facebook among Indonesian internet users, where almost 90% access it through mobile devices [6]. Social media platforms like Facebook and Instagram are not only popular for communication but also serve as significant channels for e-commerce activities, particularly "F-commerce" or Facebook commerce [3].

Moreover, entertainment activities such as games and video streaming also occupy a substantial portion of mobile internet usage, with games/apps being the most downloaded content at 70% [image3]. This suggests that mobile users in Indonesia spend considerable time on leisure activities, which could influence their online shopping behavior. For instance, users might come across advertisements or product recommendations while engaging in these activities, potentially leading to purchases.

When we look at the comparison chart of offline and online shopping preferences, apparel is the most purchased item both offline (79.2%) and online (67.1%) [image1]. This indicates a strong interest in fashion, which ties back to the prevalence of fashion and apparel sales through mobile platforms like BBM Groups [3]. Additionally, the growing trend of mobile shopping is supported by the fact that 36% of media consumption is via mobile devices, with mobile influencing 55% of customer decisions [4].

In conclusion, the predominant mobile internet activities in Indonesia, especially social media and entertainment, significantly influence online shopping behaviors, with fashion and apparel being a key category in both online and offline shopping. The integration of social media and mobile platforms has fostered an environment conducive to e-commerce growth in Indonesia.

The demographics of mobile internet users in Indonesia reveal a young and entrepreneurial user base, which significantly influences their mobile content preferences and presents unique business opportunities. According to the data, 32% of mobile users are aged between 18-24 years, and 33% fall within the 25-35 age range [image3]. This youthful demographic is highly engaged with social media and instant messaging services; for instance, 92% of internet users own a Facebook account, and 60% use IM multiple times daily [5].

The most downloaded mobile content aligns well with this young audience's interests. Games and apps dominate downloads at 70%, followed by video content at 49% ![{Games and apps are the most downloaded mobile content}](image2). This preference for entertainment and interactive applications suggests a lucrative market for developers and advertisers targeting these categories.

Moreover, the significant presence of businessmen and entrepreneurs among mobile internet users (one-fourth) indicates a robust potential for e-commerce and digital marketing. E-commerce platforms like Tokobagus/OLX have experienced substantial growth on mobile, with an 800% increase in Android app usage [9]. Additionally, the rise of IM groups as a popular platform for online shopping (27%) highlights the opportunity for businesses to leverage these channels for direct sales and customer engagement [3].

Business opportunities also extend to payment services, as evidenced by the variety of PSP services available, such as Coda Payments and Mandiri e-cash, catering to both banked and unbanked users ![{PSP services cater to diverse payment needs}](image1).

In conclusion, the demographics of mobile internet users in Indonesia, characterized by youth and entrepreneurship, strongly influence their preferences for entertainment-rich content and create ample business opportunities in e-commerce, digital marketing, and payment services.

From the provided data, it is evident that Telkomsel experienced significant changes in its subscriber base and ARPU from 2013 to 2014. The trend of declining ARPUs across various services can be observed in a line graph [image1], which illustrates the gradual decrease in Voice and SMS ARPU over the years. Specifically, for Telkomsel, the ARPU decline was part of a broader industry trend where ARPUs were reduced due to price wars initiated by the government [3].

The bar chart comparing the number of subscribers and user types for different telecom companies provides insight into Telkomsel's growth [image4]. Telkomsel had a substantial subscriber base of 139.3 million, indicating a strong market presence. This large subscriber base likely contributed to the company's ability to maintain revenue despite the decline in ARPU.

Additionally, the increase in smartphone users (35.4 million) and data users (63.5 million) suggests a shift towards data consumption rather than traditional voice and SMS services. This aligns with the trend mentioned in the text where the usage of SMS and voice calls declined as people opted for data-based IM and VoIP services [1]. As a result, while Voice and SMS ARPU continued to flatten or decrease, the initial dip in Data ARPU eventually started to pick up as users enrolled in larger data plans [7].

Therefore, Telkomsel's subscriber base grew significantly, but the ARPU decreased due to a combination of government-initiated price wars and a shift in consumer behavior towards data-intensive services ![The image shows the trends in Average Revenue Per User (ARPU) for Voice, SMS, and Mobile Data from 2013 to 2017](image1).

In conclusion, Telkomsel's subscriber base expanded notably from 2013 to 2014, while ARPU declined primarily due to government-mandated price reductions and increased adoption of data services.

According to a bar chart comparing subscriber metrics for different telecommunications providers [image4], Telkomsel had 35.4 million smartphone users while XL had 15 million smartphone users. Although this chart provides data from around 2014, it gives us an idea of the scale of smartphone adoption by these two companies' subscribers during that period.

Regarding ARPU trends, a line graph illustrates the trends in Average Revenue Per User (ARPU) for Voice, SMS, and Mobile Data over the period from 2013 to 2017 ![{Voice and SMS ARPU showed a declining trend while Mobile Data ARPU initially declined but then increased}](image2). For both Telkomsel and XL, the Voice and SMS ARPU were on a downward trajectory, reflecting a general trend across the industry due to the shift towards data-based services like IM and VoIP [4]. Additionally, another bar chart shows the prepaid ARPU for four telecom companies, including Telkomsel and XL, for the years 2008 and 2012 ![{Both Telkomsel and XL experienced a decline in ARPU from 2008 to 2012}](image5). Specifically, Telkomsel's ARPU decreased from 53 in 2008 to 34 in 2012, and XL's ARPU dropped from 35 in 2008 to 31 in 2012. In summary, between 2013 and 2014, the number of smartphone users increased for both Telkomsel and XL, while their ARPU continued to decline, influenced by the growing adoption of smartphones and the consequent shift from traditional voice and SMS services to data-based services.

The comparison of streaming and album sales across different music genres reveals significant variations that provide insight into music consumption trends. According to the data, streaming has become a dominant force in the music industry [4]. For instance, in rock music, while album sales account for 37% of the genre's share, streams contribute 23%, indicating a relatively balanced but still growing trend towards streaming [image4].

In contrast, pop music shows a more pronounced shift towards streaming. Pop's album sales make up only 19% of its share, whereas streaming accounts for 23%, highlighting a stronger inclination towards streaming within this genre [image4]. This aligns with the observation that pop is mainly driven by current releases rather than catalog sales [3].

For R&B/Hip-Hop, the gap between album sales and streaming is even more pronounced. Album sales constitute just 18% of the genre's share, while streaming represents 26%. This suggests that R&B/Hip-Hop fans are particularly active in streaming platforms, possibly due to the genre's strong presence in playlists and on-demand listening [image4].

Country music also exhibits a notable trend, where album sales (12%) are significantly lower compared to streaming (12%), despite having a higher percentage of physical album sales [image4]. This indicates that while country music fans may still buy albums, they are increasingly engaging with streaming services.

![Streaming leads in total activity](image5) further emphasizes that overall, streaming constitutes the highest percentage of total music activity at 70%, surpassing album sales, song sales, and other forms of consumption.

In summary, the shares of streaming and album sales across different music genres suggest a growing preference for streaming over traditional album purchases, reflecting a broader shift in music consumption habits towards digital and on-demand platforms.

The contribution of streams to total music activity varies significantly between different genres and overall music consumption. According to the bar chart titled "GENRE SHARE OF TOTAL," streaming percentages for various genres are as follows: Rock at 23%, R&B/Hip-Hop at 26%, Pop at 23%, Country at 12%, Latin at 10%, Dance/Electronic at 6%, and Christian/Gospel at 3% ![{Streaming percentages vary by genre}](image1).

Furthermore, when comparing the catalog share of different music formats across genres, we see that Rock has 82% of its streams contributing to total activity, while Pop has 58%, R&B/Hip-Hop has 61%, and Country has 70% ![{Streams contribute differently to catalog activity in each genre}](image2). This indicates that although Rock has a lower percentage of streams compared to other genres in total music activity, it has a higher internal contribution within its own catalog.

In terms of total music consumption, the bar chart comparing different aspects of music consumption shows that streams account for 70% of total activity, which is notably higher than album sales (51%) and song sales (49%) ![{Streams dominate total music activity}](image4). This highlights the growing dominance of streaming in the music industry's overall consumption patterns.

Thus, the contribution of streams to total music activity differs between genres but is consistently high in total music consumption.

The catalog shares of different music formats vary significantly across genres. For instance, Rock has a notably higher share in Album Sales at 63% and Streams at 82%, indicating its strong presence in both traditional and modern listening formats [5]. In contrast, Pop shows a lower share in Album Sales at 21% but a higher share in Streams at 58%, highlighting its reliance on streaming platforms ![Rock genre has higher album sales and streams compared to other genres](image5).

Moreover, R&B/Hip-Hop demonstrates balanced activity with Album Sales at 46% and Streams at 61%, suggesting it is well-distributed across various formats. Country music also shows a strong presence in Album Sales at 54% and Streams at 70%, aligning with the general trend of country fans being more inclined towards physical and digital album purchases as well as streaming [4].

Regarding albums with the highest on-demand audio stream share, the data from the ranking list of music albums indicates that Nicki Minaj's album has the highest percentage at 18% for on-demand audio streams. Additionally, Kendrick Lamar leads in Album Share with 84%, while Maroon 5 excels in Song Sales Share at 48%. However, it is Taylor Swift who ranks first overall with a total sales volume of 1,608,000 units ![Nicki Minaj's album has the highest on-demand audio stream share](image2).

In summary, the catalog shares differ widely across genres, with Rock leading in album sales and streams, and Nicki Minaj's album having the highest on-demand audio stream share.

The distribution of music genres across different sales formats and streaming in 2015 can be analyzed through the provided data. Rock dominates album sales with a significant 37% share, followed by Pop at 19%, R&B/Hip-Hop at 18%, Country at 12%, and Latin at just 2% [image1]. For song sales, Pop takes the lead with 26%, closely followed by Rock at 24%, and R&B/Hip-Hop at 23%. Latin again has a minimal share at only 3% [image1].

When it comes to streaming, the landscape is slightly different. R&B/Hip-Hop leads with 26% of streams, followed by Rock and Pop both at 23%, while Country stands at 12% and Latin at 10% [image1]. This aligns with the statement that "R&B/Hip-Hop leads streaming" [4], indicating a strong preference for this genre in the streaming format.

To further break down the catalog activity within each genre, Rock shows the highest activity in all formats, especially in streams where it reaches 82% of its total activity ![Rock's high stream activity](image2). In contrast, Pop has a more balanced distribution but leans towards streaming with 58% of its total activity coming from streams ![Pop's moderate stream activity](image2).

Overall, the distribution of music sales across genres reveals that Physical Albums still hold a considerable share for Rock (32%) and Country (35%), while Digital Albums are more popular for Pop (15%) and R&B/Hip-Hop (20%) ![Distribution of sales formats across genres](image3). Streaming Equivalent Albums (SEA) have become a dominant force, particularly for Latin music, which has an impressive 68% SEA share ![Latin's high SEA share](image3).

In conclusion, Rock maintains a strong presence in album sales, Pop drives song sales, and R&B/Hip-Hop leads in streaming, reflecting the diverse consumption patterns of different music genres in 2015.

Streaming and album sales trends reveal significant differences across various music genres, impacting the music industry in diverse ways. These trends imply that streaming is becoming increasingly crucial for the music industry, particularly for genres like pop, R&B/Hip-Hop, and Latin. However, genres such as rock and country still maintain strong album sales, suggesting that traditional formats remain important for certain fan bases. The adoption rates of iOS and Android operating systems in Vietnam during Q2 and Q3 of 2015 can be analyzed through the provided data. - Selecting top-k nodes.
- Updating the current layer.

- Calculating dot products.
- Sorting the nodes.

- Iterating over top nodes with a condition.
- Returning the result.
This is detailed in `![{Collapsed Tree Algorithm pseudocode}](image5)`.

By comparing these two pseudocodes, it becomes evident that the Collapsed Tree Algorithm has more detailed steps involving additional operations like flattening the tree and managing token counts within a loop. Therefore, the Collapsed Tree Algorithm has more lines of pseudocode.

To determine how many years after the Chapel Bridge was the Acropolis Museum completed, we need to examine the historical information provided by the models for both structures.

First, let's identify the completion dates of each structure. According to the ground-truth data:

- The Chapel Bridge in Lucerne, Switzerland, was built in 1333 [image5].
- The Acropolis Museum opened to the public on June 20, 2009 [image3].

Now, calculating the difference between these two dates:
\[ 2009 - 1333 = 676 \]

Therefore, the Acropolis Museum was completed 676 years after the Chapel Bridge was built. 

![{The Chapel Bridge is over 700 years old, built in 1333}](image5)
![{The Acropolis Museum opened to the public on June 20, 2009}](image3)

Thus, the Acropolis Museum was completed 676 years after the Chapel Bridge.

Based on the provided evidence, VAAL (Variational Adversarial Active Learning) tends to yield the worst label diversity generally across the datasets. This conclusion is supported by multiple observations:

In the analysis of OrganAMNIST and BloodMNIST, VAAL shows a significant bias towards certain classes while largely ignoring others [6]. For instance, in OrganAMNIST, VAAL prefers selecting data from the femur-right and platelet classes but largely ignores data from lung, liver, and monocyte classes. Similarly, in BloodMNIST, VAAL's selection bias leads to an underrepresentation of minority classes.

Furthermore, ![{VAAL shows a preference for selecting data in the muscle class, ignoring mucus and mucosa}](image5) reinforces this observation. In the PathMNIST dataset, VAAL has a clear preference for the muscle class and almost completely ignores mucus and mucosa classes, leading to a highly imbalanced distribution with low entropy (2.800).

Therefore, VAAL exhibits poor label diversity across various datasets, making it the querying strategy that yields the worst label diversity generally.

The system generates a response to the user's request through a structured and interconnected process that involves several key components. Initially, the user input in natural language format is encoded into a continuous vector using a bidirectional LSTM utterance encoder [4]. This encoding, combined with the previous system action, serves as input to the dialogue-level LSTM, which maintains a continuous representation of the dialogue state.

As depicted in the proposed architecture for an end-to-end task-oriented dialogue system ![{the system processes user requests and generates relevant responses utilizing encoders, a policy network, and a natural language generator}](image2), the updated dialogue state is tracked by identifying slots or variables from the user's request. For instance, if the user asks for a movie recommendation, the system might identify "date" and "time" as relevant slots [7].

Following this, the dialogue state tracking outputs are used to formulate a query command to retrieve information from an external knowledge base [5]. The results from this query are then encoded and fed into the policy network along with the dialogue state and slot value logits [9]. The policy network uses these inputs to determine the next system dialogue act [1]. Based on the dialogue state, the estimated user’s goal, and the encoding of the query results, the policy network generates a probability distribution over candidate values for each of the tracked goal slots [3].

Finally, the emitted system action is used to produce a system response in natural language format by combining the state tracker outputs and the retrieved KB entities [6]. A template-based NLG replaces delexicalised tokens in the NLG template with values from either the estimated user goal values or the KB entities, depending on the emitted system action [4]. 

In conclusion, the system generates a response to the user's request by processing the user's input through a series of neural network components, updating the dialogue state, querying an external knowledge base, determining the next system action, and generating a natural language response.

Specifically, LLaMA 2-Chat achieves the highest scores across all three datasets: ASDiv (67.1%), SVAMP (69.2%), and MAWPS (82.4%) ![{LLaMA 2-Chat has the highest scores across all datasets in this comparison}](image1).

An example of this is illustrated in an interaction where LLaMA 2-Chat uses a SEARCH tool to find when sharks and trees first appeared on Earth and then employs a CALCULATOR tool to determine the difference in years between these two events. This ability to use tools enhances its performance in solving complex queries that require external information or calculations ![{The chatbot's ability to understand and use tools for gathering information and performing calculations}](image4).

Therefore, LLaMA 2-Chat not only excels in mathematical problem-solving but also leverages tools proficiently to enhance its responses.

The key differences in the layout and information presented on the Arizona and California driver's licenses can be highlighted by comparing specific details from each.

For the Arizona driver's license, as seen in the image, it includes a photograph of the cardholder along with personal information such as name, address, birth date, height, weight, eye and hair color, and license number. It also specifies the license class, expiration date, issue date, and indicates that the individual is both a veteran and an organ donor ![This is an image of an Arizona driver's license with detailed personal information](image2).

On the other hand, the California driver's license also contains a photo of the cardholder and presents similar personal information like name, address, date of birth, license number, and expiration date [3]. However, it notably lacks the indication of being a veteran or an organ donor. Instead, it includes additional details such as the cardholder's height, weight, eye and hair color, and specifically mentions the category of the license holder as a sample or simulated license for illustrative purposes ![This is a California driver license with detailed personal information](image3).

In summary, while both licenses share common elements such as the cardholder's photo and basic personal information, the Arizona license uniquely includes veteran and organ donor status, whereas the California license specifies that it is a sample license and does not include the veteran or organ donor indicators.

RAPTOR significantly enhances the performance of various models across different datasets and metrics. For instance, in the QuALITY dataset, RAPTOR paired with SBERT achieves an accuracy of 56.6%, which is higher than SBERT without RAPTOR at 54.9% [1]. This improvement is consistent when comparing BM25 and DPR with and without RAPTOR, where RAPTOR consistently boosts accuracy and F-1 scores ![SBERT with RAPTOR outperforms SBERT without RAPTOR in both Accuracy and Answer F1](image1).

On the QASPER dataset, RAPTOR's impact is even more pronounced. When combined with GPT-4, RAPTOR sets a new benchmark with an F-1 score of 55.7%, surpassing CoLT5 XL’s score of 53.9% [1]. Similarly, RAPTOR outperforms BM25 and DPR by significant margins across all three language models (GPT-3, GPT-4, UnifiedQA) on the QASPER dataset, with improvements ranging from 1.8 to 10.2 points [5].

In the Narrative QA dataset, RAPTOR not only excels in ROUGE-L, BLEU-1, BLEU-4, and METEOR metrics but also sets a new state-of-the-art METEOR score [9]. The enhancement provided by RAPTOR is evident when compared to BM25 and DPR, with improvements ranging from 1.7 to 7.3 points across these metrics ![Models enhanced with RAPTOR generally yield better performance across the metrics compared to those without it](image2).

Overall, RAPTOR significantly improves the accuracy and F-1 scores of different models, making it a superior choice for enhancing performance in NLP tasks. RAPTOR consistently outperforms baseline methods like BM25 and DPR, demonstrating its effectiveness across multiple datasets and metrics.

The conclusion is that RAPTOR significantly boosts the performance of different models in terms of accuracy and F-1 scores.

To understand how the error rates of Step-Back + RAG compare between TimeQA and StrategyQA, let's examine the relevant data from both text and image quotes.

For TimeQA, the error analysis reveals that Step-Back + RAG fixes 39.9% of the baseline errors while introducing only 5.6% new errors [8]. Additionally, it corrects 21.6% of RAG's errors with a relatively low introduction of 6.3% new errors ![Error distribution for TimeQA](image1).

Turning to StrategyQA, Step-Back + RAG turns 15.4% of wrong predictions into correct ones, while causing 6.1% errors in the opposite direction. Furthermore, it fixes 12.7% of RAG’s errors with an error introduction rate of just 4.4% ![Error distribution for StrategyQA](image3).

In summary, the error rates introduced by Step-Back + RAG are comparable between TimeQA and StrategyQA, with slightly lower error correction and introduction rates for StrategyQA. Specifically, Step-Back + RAG is more effective at correcting errors on TimeQA but introduces fewer new errors on StrategyQA. 

The error rates of Step-Back + RAG are slightly lower for StrategyQA compared to TimeQA.

The SnapNTell dataset distinguishes itself from other Visual Question Answering (VQA) datasets through its comprehensive and diverse features. Unlike many existing VQA datasets that focus on simple yes/no answers or choice selection [2], SnapNTell emphasizes knowledge-intensive responses and fine-grained entity recognition [1]. 

SnapNTell encompasses a wide range of categories, totaling 22 distinct categories such as landmarks, paintings, sculptures, and more, each containing a diverse set of entities [3]. Specifically, it includes 7,568 unique entities across these categories, significantly more than datasets like ViQuAE and Encyclopedic VQA [5]. For instance, ViQuAE has only 3 categories and 2,400 unique entities, while Encyclopedic VQA has 12 categories but an unspecified number of unique entities ![{SnapNTell offers a broader and deeper coverage of categories and entities compared to ViQuAE and Encyclopedic VQA}](image5).

Moreover, SnapNTell ensures that each entity is represented by 10 illustrative images, providing rich visual context for the questions and answers [4]. This contrasts with other datasets where the number of images per entity is often unspecified. Additionally, the dataset features QA pairs that explicitly mention entity names in the answers, promoting detailed and specific knowledge-based responses [6].

A comparative analysis shows that SnapNTell not only excels in the variety of categories and number of unique entities but also in the depth of knowledge required for accurate answers [9]. The average answer length in SnapNTell is 25.7 words, much longer than the averages in other datasets, indicating a higher level of detail and complexity [5]. Furthermore, SnapNTell's QA pairs are highly anonymous, enhancing the challenge and fairness of the evaluation process ![{SnapNTell provides more detailed and anonymous QA pairs compared to other datasets}](image5).

In summary, the SnapNTell dataset surpasses other VQA datasets in terms of the diversity of categories, the richness of entities, and the depth of knowledge required for answering questions.

The BERT+DSC model consistently achieves the highest F1 score across multiple datasets. For instance, on the Chinese datasets including CTB5, CTB6, and UD1.4, BERT+DSC outperforms other models with F1 scores of 97.92, 96.57, and 96.98 respectively ![{BERT+DSC model shows the highest F1 scores on Chinese datasets}](image5). Furthermore, for the English WSJ dataset, BERT-Tagger+DSC also demonstrates a significant improvement with an F1 score of 99.38 ![{BERT-Tagger+DSC has the highest F1 score on English WSJ}](image2).

On the **English OntoNotes 5.0 dataset**, as shown in the comparison table, the base BERT-MRC model achieves a Precision of 92.98, Recall of 89.95, and an F1-score of 91.11 [1]. The enhanced versions perform as follows:
- **BERT-MRC+FL** achieves an F1-score of 91.22 (+0.11),

The DeClarE (Full) configuration, which integrates biLSTM, attention mechanism, and source embeddings, demonstrates superior performance compared to other models in terms of error metrics. When evaluating the Mean Squared Error (MSE) for credibility rating prediction on the NewsTrust dataset, DeClarE (Full) achieves an MSE of 0.29, marking a significant improvement over other configurations such as CNN-text (0.53), CCRF+SVR (0.36), LSTM-text (0.35), DistantSup (0.35), and DeClarE (Plain) (0.34) [4]. These figures are higher than those of the AttentiveNER++ (51.7% accuracy, 70.9% Ma-F1, 64.9% Mi-F1), AFET (55.1% accuracy, 71.1% Ma-F1, 64.7% Mi-F1), and LNR (57.2% accuracy, 71.5% Ma-F1, 66.1% Mi-F1) models.

For instance, the 'Ours' model trained on ONTO, WIKI, and HEAD data reaches an accuracy of 61.6%, a macro-averaged F1-score of 77.3%, and a micro-averaged F1-score of 71.8%, surpassing the Attn. The model that achieves the highest F1-value for Named Entity Recognition (NER) is the "CCNN+WLSTM+CRF" model, with an F1-value of 91.35 [4]. This model's superior performance can be attributed to several key features and architectural choices.

Firstly, the model incorporates both character-level and word-level information effectively. The character-level embeddings are processed through a CNN (Convolutional Neural Network), which captures local features from characters, denoted as CCNN in the model name ![{Character-level embeddings processed through CNN}](image1). Additionally, word-level embeddings are processed using LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory), which is adept at capturing long-range dependencies in sequences, indicated by WLSTM [6].

Moreover, the inclusion of a CRF (Conditional Random Field) layer in the inference process allows the model to consider the entire sequence when making predictions, enhancing coherence and accuracy in entity recognition [7]. The effectiveness of this combination is also supported by empirical evidence shown in a comparison table, where adding character-level features significantly improves the F1-score over models without such features ![{Table comparing model performance with different features}](image2).

In summary, the "CCNN+WLSTM+CRF" model achieves the highest F1-value for NER due to its integration of character-level CNNs, word-level LSTMs, and a CRF layer for sequence prediction.

The CO₂ emissions from training NLP models can be quite significant when compared to everyday activities. For instance, the estimated CO₂ emissions for training common NLP models are comparable to familiar consumption activities [5]. Training a model like BERT on a GPU emits CO₂ equivalent to a trans-American flight, which produces around 1,984 lbs of CO₂e as seen in ![{Air travel between New York and San Francisco emits 1,984 lbs of CO₂e}](image5).

Moreover, the energy required to train these models is substantial, especially considering the computational resources involved. For example, training 24 models can result in cloud compute costs ranging from $1238 to $4205 and electric costs of $118, reflecting the extensive use of power and resources ![{Training 24 models incurs significant cloud and electric costs}](image3). 

When we look at the breakdown of energy sources used by major tech companies, it becomes evident that even though some companies like Google have a higher reliance on renewables (56%), others such as Amazon-AWS still heavily depend on coal (30%) ![{Tech companies vary in their reliance on renewable energy sources}](image1). This means that the environmental impact of training models can vary depending on the energy mix used by the data centers.

In summary, the CO₂ emissions from training NLP models can be significantly high, often equating to or exceeding the emissions from everyday activities such as air travel.

From the provided data, BERT (Large) has the highest test median score of 0.712 [1]. This is evident from the performance metrics where BERT's median score stands out compared to other models like BoV and BiLSTM.

The architecture of the BERT model used in these experiments involves a specific way of processing input segments. The claim and reason are joined to form the first text segment, which is then paired with each warrant and processed independently [2]. This setup can be visualized in the diagram that illustrates how claims, reasons, and warrants are tokenized and input into the BERT model `![{BERT processes claims, reasons, and warrants through various layers marked by interconnected nodes}](image5)`.

Each pair of argument-warrant inputs goes through the BERT layers, marked by special tokens like [CLS] and [SEP], to signify classification and separation tasks. The final layer CLS vector is passed to a linear layer to obtain the logits [2]. These logits are then used for further processing to achieve the model's predictions. 

In conclusion, BERT (Large) has the highest test median score, and its architecture is designed to process claims, reasons, and warrants as separate yet interconnected segments through deep layers within BERT.

The COMET model demonstrates superior performance compared to other models in terms of BLEU-2 and average event understanding metrics. Specifically, the BLEU-2 score for COMET reaches 15.10, which is significantly higher than scores from other models like NearestNeighbor at 6.61 ![{COMET shows superior BLEU-2 and N/U o metrics compared to other models listed.}(image1)]. This indicates that COMET generates outputs that are more similar to human-generated references.

Moreover, when evaluating event understanding metrics, COMET also outperforms other models. For instance, in the evaluation of various relations such as oEffect, oReact, oWant, xAttr, xEffect, xIntent, xNeed, xReact, and xWant, COMET consistently achieves higher scores [3]. The average score across these relations for COMET is notably higher than its competitors, underscoring its effectiveness in comprehending and generating commonsense knowledge [9].

Additionally, the performance improvement of COMET is consistent across every relation type, not only in quality but also in producing more novel tuple objects [3]. These results are further supported by a human evaluation, where COMET reported an 18% relative average performance increase over the top baseline [2]. Therefore, COMET excels in both automatic and human evaluations, showcasing its robustness and versatility in generating high-quality commonsense knowledge. 

In conclusion, the COMET model performs better than other models in terms of BLEU-2 and average event understanding metrics.

The performance of the BiDAF and FastQA models on the WikiHop and MedHop datasets can be analyzed by comparing their results under both standard and gold chain conditions. According to the provided data, the performance metrics for these models are summarized in a table ![{The table presents the performance of different models on two datasets: WikiHop and MedHop}](image2).

On the **WikiHop** dataset, under the **standard condition**, BiDAF achieves test accuracies of 42.9% and 49.7% (validated samples), while FastQA reaches 25.7% and 27.2%. This indicates that BiDAF significantly outperforms FastQA in this setting [1]. Under the **gold chain condition**, where only relevant documents are considered, BiDAF's performance improves to 57.9% and 63.4%, whereas FastQA's accuracy rises to 44.5% and 53.5%. This suggests that both models benefit from having access to only relevant documents, but BiDAF still maintains a higher performance advantage [1].

For the **MedHop** dataset, under the **standard condition**, BiDAF scores 47.8% and 61.2% (validated samples), and FastQA scores 23.1% and 24.5%. Similar to WikiHop, BiDAF performs better than FastQA under standard conditions. When considering only relevant documents under the **gold chain condition**, BiDAF's accuracy jumps to 86.4% and 89.8%, while FastQA's increases to 54.6% and 59.2%. Again, BiDAF shows superior performance, especially when given only relevant documents [1].

In conclusion, BiDAF consistently outperforms FastQA on both the WikiHop and MedHop datasets under both standard and gold chain conditions.
