According to the data, there is a notable difference in preferences among age groups regarding promoting human rights over economic relations with China. For instance, younger Americans aged 18-29 are more inclined towards prioritizing human rights, with 76% advocating for this stance compared to only 21% who prioritize economic relations [3]. Similarly, those aged 30-49 show a preference for human rights promotion at 75%, with just 22% favoring economic relations [3].

For older Americans aged 50 and above, while still a majority, the preference for human rights promotion is slightly less pronounced at 71%, with 24% opting for economic relations [3]. This trend aligns with the broader sentiment that older Americans tend to have more negative views of China overall [2].

![{Overall, 73% of Americans advocate for promoting human rights over economic relations with China, with varying percentages across different age groups.}](image3)

In conclusion, younger age groups are more likely to prioritize human rights over economic relations with China compared to older age groups, but all age groups lean significantly towards human rights promotion.

The generational breakdown of self-identified Hispanics and non-Hispanics provides insight into how heritage identification changes across generations. Among self-identified Hispanics, 18% are foreign born, 29% are second generation, and 65% are third or higher generation [4]. In contrast, among self-identified non-Hispanics, a striking 96% belong to the third or higher generation ![{Most non-Hispanics are from the third or higher generation}](image4).

This significant difference suggests that as generations progress, the connection to Hispanic heritage diminishes. For instance, while 82% of immigrant Hispanics feel very or somewhat connected to their country of origin, this connection drops to 44% by the third generation [4]. Additionally, the likelihood of living in neighborhoods predominantly shared with others of similar heritage decreases from 41% for both foreign-born and second-generation Hispanics to 30% for third or higher generation Hispanics [10].

Furthermore, cultural practices such as speaking Spanish and having a Spanish last name also decline with each successive generation. While 41% of foreign-born Hispanics speak Spanish, only 7% of third or higher generation Hispanics do so ![{Spanish language proficiency declines significantly with each generation}](image5). Similarly, the preference for identifying with country of origin or heritage (preferred by 50% of self-identified Hispanics) may weaken over time as American identity becomes more prominent [3] ![{Country of origin is the most preferred term for self-identification among Hispanics}](image3).

In summary, the generational breakdown reveals that as generations advance, there is a notable shift away from traditional Hispanic heritage identifiers, indicating a gradual assimilation into broader American culture.

The unfavorable views of both the Republican and Democratic parties have significantly changed over time among different political affiliations. According to the data, there has been a notable increase in polarization, with growing unfavorable views of the opposite party among partisan groups [4].

From 1994 to 2018, the percentage of Democrats with an unfavorable view of the Republican Party rose from 59% to 88%, while for those leaning Democrat, it increased from around 48% to 84%. Similarly, Republicans' unfavorable views of the Democratic Party climbed from 77% to 87%, and for Republican leaners, it went up from approximately 64% to 81% ![Unfavorable views have surged over time](image4).

Additionally, independents also showed an increase in unfavorable views of the Republican Party from 24% in 1994 to 56% in 2018, and for the Democratic Party from 42% to 52% over the same period [1]. This trend reflects a growing divide and increasing negativity towards the opposing party across various political affiliations.

In conclusion, unfavorable views of both parties have increased sharply over time among Republicans, Democrats, and even independents, indicating heightened polarization in American politics.

Public opinion regarding anti-terror policies has undergone a significant shift from 2004 to 2015. Initially, in 2004, there was a more balanced view with 49% of the public feeling that the country had not gone far enough to protect itself, while 29% believed that policies had gone too far in restricting civil liberties [3]. However, by 2015, this balance had tipped significantly, with 56% expressing concern that anti-terrorism policies have not gone far enough to protect the country, and only 28% worrying about excessive restrictions on civil liberties [7]. This trend is also visually represented in a line graph ![{The graph shows a shift from concerns about civil liberties to concerns about protection over time}](image3).

Furthermore, this shift in public opinion has been particularly pronounced among Republicans. In July 2013, only 38% of Republicans were concerned that anti-terrorism policies did not go far enough, but by 2015, this number had risen to 71% [2]. The increasing concern for national protection over civil liberties can be observed across various age groups as well. For instance, while younger adults aged 18-29 are still more likely to believe that policies have gone too far in restricting civil liberties (43%), older adults aged 65+ predominantly feel that more measures are needed to protect the U.S. (71%) ![{The table shows varying opinions on civil liberties and protection across different age groups}](image1).

In conclusion, public opinion has shifted towards greater concern that anti-terrorism policies have not gone far enough to protect the country from 2004 to 2015.

Evaluations of the U.S. COVID-19 response vary significantly across different educational levels. Americans with higher education levels tend to be more critical of the U.S. response to the pandemic. For instance, around two-thirds of those with a postgraduate degree believe that the U.S. has done a poor job handling the outbreak, as do around six-in-ten college graduates [5]. In contrast, about four-in-ten of those with only a high school degree or less share this negative view [5].

This trend is also reflected in the belief that the U.S. can learn from other countries regarding effective ways to combat the coronavirus. People with higher levels of education are more likely to hold this belief compared to those with lower education levels [2]. Furthermore, individuals with postgraduate degrees are more inclined to think that the U.S.’s global position will decline after the pandemic, compared to those with only a high school diploma [7].

The data from a survey visualized in a bar chart further supports these findings ![Higher education correlates with more critical views on U.S. pandemic response](image4). The chart shows that 62% of postgraduates rate the U.S. response as "Only fair/poor," while 36% rate it as "Good/excellent." This contrasts with those who have a high school degree or less, where 62% also rate the response as "Only fair/poor" but slightly more at 34% rate it as "Good/excellent."

In conclusion, evaluations of the U.S. COVID-19 response are more critical among individuals with higher educational attainment.

The perception of the U.S. as the world's leading economic power has undergone notable changes among both Democrats and Republicans over the years. According to the data, while the views on this matter have shifted, there are distinct differences in how each party perceives it.

From 2008 to 2020, the percentage of Republicans who identified or leaned Republican (Rep/Lean Rep) increased from 54% to 64%, indicating a growing support base for the Republican party [image4]. This shift likely influenced their perception of the U.S. economy. In contrast, the percentage of Democrats who identified or leaned Democratic (Dem/Lean Dem) only slightly increased from 43% to 44% over the same period [image4].

In more recent times, the perception of the U.S. as the leading global economy has seen a decline among Democrats. Specifically, the share of Democrats who see the U.S. as the leading global economy dropped from 54% in March to 44% today [1]. This decline suggests a growing skepticism within the Democratic party regarding the U.S.'s economic dominance.

On the other hand, Republicans' views on this question have mostly held steady over the past four months [1], suggesting less fluctuation in their perception of the U.S. economy compared to Democrats. Additionally, Republicans have shown a significant increase in viewing China as an enemy, with a 21 percentage point rise since 2012, whereas Democrats have seen an 8 percentage point increase, widening the gap between the two parties [7].

Furthermore, the general trend shows that Americans have become more negative about bilateral economic ties with China, with a 15-point increase among Republicans and a 12-point increase among Democrats over the past year [2]. This growing negativity might also reflect a broader concern about the U.S.'s position as the leading economic power.

![{Increasing levels of "No confidence at all" over time}](image2)

Overall, the perception of the U.S. as the world's leading economic power has declined more significantly among Democrats than Republicans from 2008 to 2020.

The population trends of Hamilton County, Nebraska, from 1870 to 2000 show a significant initial surge followed by a gradual decline. In 1870, the population was just 130, but by 1890 it had reached its peak at 14,096 [5]. This rapid growth can be attributed to the influence of two major congressional acts in the mid-1800s: the Transcontinental Railroad Act and the Homestead Act, both passed in 1862 [9]. The railroad facilitated easier access to the region, while the Homestead Act provided incentives for settlers to claim land, leading to a "great tide of emigration" that transformed Nebraska into a booming agricultural state [9].

However, after reaching its peak in 1890, the population began to slowly decline [5]. By 1900, the population had dropped slightly to 13,330, and continued to decrease through subsequent decades, as shown in the population data ![Population decreased gradually over the years](image3). This decline is partly due to farm consolidation, which has been a significant trend since the early 20th century [4]. Mechanization and increased costs of operation led to fewer but larger farms, reducing the number of small farming communities that once thrived in Hamilton County.

Despite this overall trend, some towns within Hamilton County have experienced recent population gains, such as Aurora, which peaked in population in 2000 with 4,225 citizens [2]. However, outside of Aurora, many other towns have struggled to maintain their populations [2].

The establishment of ethnic enclaves also played a role in shaping the county's demographics. For example, the Danish community around Kronborg centered on St. John’s Lutheran Church, which continues to serve as a focal point for the community ![St. John’s Lutheran Church in Kronborg remains a significant landmark](image1) [7]. Similarly, the German settlement near Zion Lutheran Church highlights the importance of these ethnic groups in forming strong religious congregations and rural complexes [1].

In conclusion, the population trends of Hamilton County from 1870 to 2000 were influenced by federal policies promoting settlement, changes in agricultural practices, and the formation of ethnic enclaves. The county saw a dramatic increase in population during the late 19th century, followed by a gradual decline driven by farm consolidation and changing economic conditions.

The confidence levels in Trump's ability to work effectively with Congress and negotiate trade agreements differ significantly between Republicans and Democrats. 

Republicans are generally more confident in Trump's abilities across various issues, but even among them, working effectively with Congress is rated lower compared to other tasks. According to the data, 70% of Republicans express at least some confidence in Trump’s ability to work with Congress, but only 31% are very confident [1]. In contrast, for negotiating favorable trade agreements, nearly nine-in-ten Republicans (89%) are confident, with 67% being very confident ![{Republicans show high confidence in Trump's trade negotiation skills}](image4).

On the other hand, Democrats exhibit much lower confidence in both areas. Only 19% of Democrats and Democratic leaners are confident in Trump’s ability to negotiate trade agreements [5], while just 2% are very confident and 5% somewhat confident in his ability to work with Congress ![{Democrats have very low confidence in Trump's congressional cooperation}](image4). This stark difference underscores a significant partisan divide.

Overall, the public’s confidence in Trump's ability to negotiate trade agreements is higher than his ability to work with Congress. About half of Americans express at least some confidence in his trade negotiation skills, while confidence in his congressional cooperation is notably lower, with only about a third expressing confidence [8]. 

In conclusion, Republicans have higher confidence in Trump’s ability to negotiate trade agreements compared to working with Congress, whereas Democrats have very low confidence in both areas, especially in his ability to work with Congress.

The distribution of EU VC funds in quartile rankings, when benchmarked against the US, reveals a notable difference in performance concentration. In the US, the distribution is uniform across all quartiles, with each quartile representing 25% of the total 373 funds [1]. Conversely, the EU VC funds show a skewed distribution, with a higher concentration in the top quartile. Specifically, 35% of EU VC funds fall into the top quartile, while the remaining quartiles have fewer funds: 25% in Q2, 17% in Q3, and 23% in the bottom quartile ![EU VC funds have a higher share in the top quartile compared to other quartiles](image1).

This suggests that European venture capital funds are performing better relative to their US counterparts, particularly at the top end of the performance spectrum. However, it is important to note that visibility on European VC fund performance is limited due to less stringent publication requirements, which may affect the completeness and accuracy of this data [4].

In conclusion, the EU VC funds exhibit a higher proportion in the top quartile compared to the even distribution seen in the US VC funds.

The partisan views on whether Obama is "not tough enough" on foreign policy exhibit significant differences. According to the data, a substantial majority of Republicans hold this view, with 84% believing that Obama’s approach is not tough enough [2]. This sentiment is shared by a smaller but still notable portion of Independents, where 61% agree that Obama's stance is insufficiently tough [7].

In contrast, Democrats are more divided. The overall percentage of Democrats who think Obama is not tough enough stands at 35%, while 58% believe his approach is about right [8]. Among Democrats, the divide is further nuanced by ideology; conservative and moderate Democrats are more likely to feel Obama is not tough enough (45%), whereas liberal Democrats are less inclined to agree (26%) [8].

Over time, the perception that Obama is not tough enough has increased across all groups, rising from 53% in July to 58% currently [5]. This trend is also reflected in public opinion over the years, as shown in a table indicating an increasing trend in the belief that Obama is "not tough enough," starting at 38% in June 2009 and reaching 58% by December 2015 ![{the belief that Obama is 'not tough enough' has increased from 38% in 2009 to 58% in 2015}](image1).

Overall, Republicans are significantly more likely than Democrats to perceive Obama as not tough enough on foreign policy, with Independents falling between these two groups.

Americans exhibit a strong preference for limiting machines to dangerous or unhealthy jobs compared to other automation policies. Specifically, 85% of Americans favor the idea of restricting robots and computers to primarily perform jobs that are dangerous or unhealthy for humans [1]. This widespread support is evident across different political affiliations, as shown in the bar chart where both Democrats/lean Dem (85%) and Republicans/lean Rep (86%) have high levels of agreement ![Support for policies among Democrats and Republicans](image2).

When we compare this sentiment to other policies, the support for limiting machines to dangerous jobs stands out as particularly robust. For instance, while 62% of Americans support giving people the option to pay extra to interact with a human worker instead of a machine, this figure is notably lower than the 85% who favor limiting machines to dangerous jobs [1]. Similarly, policies such as providing all Americans with a guaranteed income (60%) and creating a government-run national service program (58%) also receive less support compared to the policy of restricting machines to hazardous tasks [1].

Moreover, the public's inclination towards limiting the number of jobs businesses can replace with machines is also significant but not as overwhelming; 58% of Americans believe there should be limits on job replacement by machines, which again is lower than the support for limiting machines to dangerous jobs ![Public opinion on various automation policies](image5).

In conclusion, Americans feel much more strongly about limiting machines to dangerous jobs compared to other automation policies, with an overwhelming majority supporting this specific measure.

Age significantly influences opinions on limiting Chinese students in U.S. universities, with older Americans generally more supportive of such limitations compared to younger adults. For instance, among those aged 50 and older, roughly seven-in-ten are in favor of limiting Chinese students [6]. In contrast, nearly two-thirds of Americans aged 18 to 29 oppose the idea ![{Ages 18-29 have a higher opposition rate}](image5).

Moreover, this trend aligns with broader attitudes toward China, where older Americans express more concern about China-related issues and are more likely to view China negatively. Specifically, 53% of those aged 65 and older have no confidence at all in the Chinese president, while only 35% of those aged 18 to 29 share this view [1]. Similarly, older adults are significantly more likely than younger ones to describe China as an enemy, with 49% of those aged 65 and older considering China an enemy compared to just 20% of those under 30 [8].

These age-related differences also extend to the perceived impact of Chinese students on the U.S., where older respondents tend to see it as a more significant issue. The data shows that while overall 55% of Americans support limiting Chinese students, the support is much stronger among older demographics [7]. Conversely, younger people are more likely to stress building a stronger relationship with China over taking a tougher stance [4].

In conclusion, age plays a crucial role in shaping opinions on limiting Chinese students in U.S. universities, with older Americans being more supportive of such limitations than their younger counterparts.

Americans exhibit a notably lower level of confidence in President Biden's ability to deal effectively with China compared to other foreign policy issues. Specifically, around half of Americans (53%) have confidence in Biden's handling of the U.S.-China relationship [3]. This percentage is lower than the confidence levels for other foreign policy areas such as improving relationships with allies (67%), dealing with terrorism and global climate change (both at 60%), and making decisions about military force and international trade (both at 59%) [3].

This disparity in confidence is also reflected in partisan views. Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents show much higher confidence (83%) in Biden's approach to China than Republicans and Republican leaners (19%) [5]. The chart in ![{Partisan differences in perceptions towards China are significant, especially on economic issues}](image1) visually underscores these stark contrasts between Democrats and Republicans on various aspects of U.S.-China relations.

Furthermore, demographic factors influence this confidence as well. Women (59%) express more confidence in Biden’s ability to handle China than men (48%). Similarly, Black adults (82%) and Hispanic adults (70%) are more confident than White adults (43%), and those with a college degree (60%) are more confident than those with less education (50%) [9].

In conclusion, fewer Americans have confidence in Biden to handle the U.S.-China relationship compared to other foreign policy issues.

In 2008, after Barack Obama's election, there was a more unified call for bipartisanship compared to the divided opinions in 2016 following Donald Trump's victory. Specifically, in 2008, 74% of all voters believed that Republican leaders should work with Obama [5]. Among Republicans or those leaning Republican, 59% supported working with Obama, while 36% preferred standing up to him [image2]. In contrast, by 2016, only 59% of all voters thought Democratic leaders should work with Trump, even if it means disappointing their supporters, while 39% felt they should stand up to Trump on important issues [image2].

Moreover, in 2008, nearly eight-in-ten (78%) of Obama’s voters said that Democratic leaders should work with Republicans even at the risk of disappointing their supporters [5]. This contrasts sharply with 2016, where just 32% of Clinton voters wanted Democratic leaders to work with Trump, while 65% preferred standing up to him [image2]. The significant shift in voter sentiment is also reflected in the partisan divide; in 2008, 86% of Democrats wanted Republicans to work with Obama, whereas in 2016, only 32% of Democrats wanted to cooperate with Trump [image2].

Additionally, the graph showing the perception of mudslinging in elections indicates an increasingly negative campaign environment, with 92% of voters perceiving more mudslinging in 2016 compared to past elections ![The percentage of voters who perceived more mudslinging increased significantly over time, reaching 92% in 2016](image1). This suggests a deteriorating political climate which may have influenced the less cooperative stance among voters in 2016.

In summary, voter opinions shifted from a more collaborative approach in 2008 to a more confrontational stance in 2016 regarding political leaders working with newly elected presidents.

The opinions of Americans and Germans on national defense spending have shown interesting trends from 2017 to 2019. In the U.S., there has been a shift towards favoring stability in defense spending by European allies, as opposed to an increase. Specifically, in 2017, 45% of Americans felt that European allies should increase their defense budgets, but this number dropped to 35% by 2019 [10]. Meanwhile, the percentage of Americans who believed spending levels should remain the same increased from 37% in 2017 to 50% in 2019 ![{Opinions shifted more towards maintaining current spending levels}](image5).

In Germany, the public is divided on whether to increase or maintain current levels of defense spending [7]. Initially, in 2017, about half of Germans were content with their country’s defense spending, while about a third felt it should be increased. By 2019, 40% supported an increase, 41% favored keeping it the same, and 15% supported a decrease ![{Germans showed a slight preference for increasing defense spending over maintaining it}](image5). This indicates a slight increase in support for higher defense spending compared to 2017, but still shows a division in opinion.

Overall, the data shows that both Americans and Germans have seen shifts in their views on national defense spending, with Americans increasingly favoring stable spending levels and Germans showing a slight inclination towards increasing spending over maintaining it.

According to the data from the Pew Research Center's survey conducted by Princeton Survey Research Associates International from July 18 to September 30, 2013 [8], we can analyze the online behavior of older adults using both textual and visual data.

The pie chart visually breaks down the categories of online usage among older adults ![The pie chart shows different categories of online usage: 41% "Do not go online", 32% "Go online, no SNS", and 27% "Use SNS"](image1). From this chart, we see that 41% of older adults do not go online at all. Additionally, 32% of older adults go online but do not use social networking sites (SNS).

Combining these percentages, the total proportion of older adults who either do not go online or only use social networking sites is the sum of those who do not go online (41%) and those who use SNS (27%). Therefore, 68% of older adults either do not go online or are limited to using social networking sites.

In conclusion, 68% of older adults either do not go online or only use social networking sites based on the provided data.

Public opinions on the effectiveness of the U.S. response to the coronavirus outbreak reveal a largely critical stance. According to the survey, about six-in-ten Americans (62%) believe that the U.S. response has been less effective compared with other wealthy countries [3]. This sentiment is further emphasized by the fact that only 13% of Americans say the U.S. response has been more effective, while a quarter think it has been about as effective [9].

The partisan divide on this issue is also notable. While 87% of Democrats and Democratic leaners view the U.S. response as less effective compared with other wealthy countries, only 34% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents share this view, with just 22% believing the U.S. has been more effective [2]. 

This criticism extends to concerns over the lifting of restrictions. A sizable majority of 69% of U.S. adults are worried that state governments have been lifting restrictions too quickly ![{69% of respondents believe restrictions are being lifted too quickly}](image2). Additionally, there is a strong preference for prioritizing health measures over economic reopening; 73% of Americans believe that significantly reducing the number of infections is the more effective way to help the economy recover ![{73% prioritize reducing infections for economic recovery}](image1).

Overall, public opinion indicates a predominantly negative assessment of the U.S. response to the coronavirus outbreak, with a significant portion of the population expressing concerns about the speed of lifting restrictions and favoring health measures over rapid economic reopening.

In conclusion, the majority of Americans view the U.S. response to the coronavirus outbreak as less effective compared to other wealthy countries.

The Soft Launch and Full Launch had slightly different initial invitation dates but shared the same reminder schedule. From December 2014 to December 2015, there was a notable shift in public concerns from economic issues to terrorism. In December 2014, 34% of the public named an economic issue as the most important problem facing the nation [1]. However, by December 2015, this percentage dropped significantly to just 23%, with only 9% citing the economy and 7% mentioning unemployment [1].

Conversely, concerns about terrorism saw a dramatic increase over the same period. In December 2014, only 4% of the public cited terrorism, national security, or ISIS as the most important problem. By December 2015, this figure surged to 29%, with 18% specifically citing terrorism, 8% national security, and 7% ISIS [8]. This rise reflects a significant change in public perception, likely influenced by global events and increased media coverage of terrorist activities.

The data is also corroborated by a survey table that shows the percentage of respondents mentioning each issue [image4]. The table highlights a substantial increase in concerns related to terrorism and national security, while economic concerns saw a decline. Specifically, the concern over terrorism rose from 1% to 18%, and defense/national security from 2% to 8%. Meanwhile, general economic concerns fell from 14% to 9%, and unemployment from 10% to 7%.

In conclusion, public concerns shifted markedly from economic issues to terrorism between December 2014 and December 2015, reflecting broader changes in the national agenda ![concerns shifted markedly from economic issues to terrorism](image4).

According to the data, preferences for prioritizing the needs of Trump's supporters significantly differ between Trump and Clinton voters. Among all voters, 51% believe that Trump will give equal priority to all Americans, while 46% think he will prioritize his supporters [6]. However, when we break this down by voter group, we see a stark contrast.

Trump voters overwhelmingly hold the view that Trump will give equal priority to all Americans. Specifically, 84% of Trump voters believe this, whereas only 16% think he will prioritize his supporters [4]. This aligns with the sentiment that Trump voters have a strong belief in Trump’s leadership direction [3], as shown in the image where 87% of Trump voters feel they have a clear idea of where Trump wants to lead the country `![{87% of Trump voters have a good idea of where Trump wants to lead the country}](image2)`.

On the other hand, Clinton voters predominantly think Trump will prioritize his supporters over others. A substantial 75% of Clinton voters believe that Trump will give greater priority to the needs of his supporters, while only 20% think he will treat everyone equally [4]. This perception is consistent with the broader skepticism among Clinton voters regarding Trump’s intentions and policies [7].

In conclusion, Trump voters are much more likely to believe that Trump will give equal priority to all Americans, while Clinton voters predominantly expect him to prioritize his supporters.

The racial identification among self-identified Hispanics varies significantly across different generations. For foreign-born Hispanics, a substantial majority identify as Hispanic or Latino, with 78% selecting this category compared to only 11% who identify as White [5]. This strong identification with Hispanic or Latino heritage is also reflected in the image data, which shows that 78% of foreign-born Hispanics identify as Hispanic or Latino, reinforcing their close ties to their ancestral identity `![{Foreign-born Hispanics strongly identify as Hispanic or Latino}](image5)`.

For second-generation Hispanics, there is a noticeable shift in racial identification. While still a majority, the percentage identifying as Hispanic or Latino drops to 66%, and the share identifying as White increases to 15% [5]. This suggests that second-generation Hispanics may feel a stronger connection to both their Hispanic heritage and broader American identity `![{Second-generation Hispanics show a mix of Hispanic and White identification}](image5)`.

By the third or higher generation, the identification with Hispanic or Latino heritage further diminishes. Only 46% of these individuals identify as Hispanic or Latino, while 25% identify as White [5]. This trend indicates a growing assimilation into mainstream American society, where the influence of Hispanic ancestry on racial identity becomes less pronounced over time `![{Third or higher generation Hispanics have lower Hispanic identification and higher White identification}](image5)`.

In conclusion, racial identification among self-identified Hispanics decreases from foreign-born to third or higher generation, with an increasing proportion identifying as White.

The perceptions of workplace discrimination and fairness significantly differ among racial/ethnic groups in STEM jobs. For instance, 62% of blacks in STEM report experiencing any of eight types of racial or ethnic discrimination, which is notably higher than the percentages reported by Asians (44%), Hispanics (42%), and whites (13%) [7]. This disparity is further emphasized in the comparative chart that highlights a significant difference in experiences of discrimination at work; 62% of Black respondents reported experiencing discrimination compared to only 13% of White respondents ![{Black respondents report higher levels of discrimination}](image3).

Moreover, when it comes to the perception of fair treatment in recruitment and hiring processes, there is a marked difference between black and white STEM workers. Only 43% of blacks in STEM jobs believe that blacks are usually treated fairly during recruitment, whereas 78% of white STEM workers hold this belief [5]. Similarly, for promotion and advancement opportunities, 37% of blacks feel these processes are fair, contrasting sharply with 75% of whites who perceive them as fair ![{Blacks perceive less fairness in promotion opportunities}](image3).

Additionally, blacks in STEM jobs are more likely to view racial and ethnic diversity in the workplace as extremely or very important (84% vs. 49% of whites), indicating a greater emphasis on diversity from this group [8]. The same image also reveals that 57% of Black respondents feel their workplace pays insufficient attention to diversity issues, while only 15% of White respondents share this sentiment ![{Blacks feel workplaces pay insufficient attention to diversity}](image3).

In conclusion, blacks in STEM jobs perceive higher levels of workplace discrimination and less fairness in recruitment and promotion processes compared to other racial/ethnic groups.

Trump's voter grades in 2016 were notably lower compared to other winning candidates since 1988. According to the Pew Research Center survey, only 30% of voters gave Trump an A or B for how he conducted himself during the campaign [8]. This is significantly lower than previous winning candidates and marks the lowest such grade for any victorious candidate in 28 years.

Moreover, nearly two-thirds of Clinton voters (65%) gave Trump a failing grade, which is the highest percentage among election winners dating back to 1988 [1]. In contrast, Hillary Clinton received higher grades from voters; about four-in-ten (43%) gave her an A or B, which is 13 percentage points higher than Trump’s rating [6].

Additionally, Trump supporters were not as positive about the performance of the voters as Obama supporters were in previous elections. For instance, 83% of Obama supporters gave high grades in 2008, while only 55% of Trump supporters awarded top grades to the voters [4].

The sentiment among Clinton voters was also reflected in their willingness to give Trump a chance, with 58% willing to see how he governs, but 39% unable to do so due to their perception of him ![{58% of Clinton voters were willing to give Trump a chance, while 39% could not}](image3).

In conclusion, Trump's voter grades in 2016 were the lowest for any winning candidate since 1988.

Specifically, 70% of respondents think the U.S. can learn from Germany [8], and similarly, 70% believe the U.S. can learn from South Korea ![{Germany and South Korea are perceived as leading examples for the U.S. to learn from}](image3).

This aligns with the broader sentiment that Americans generally have a positive view of how these two countries handle the coronavirus outbreak [9]. The belief that the U.S. can learn from other countries is also more prevalent among those with higher education levels [4], further supporting the high percentages for Germany and South Korea.

In conclusion, Germany and South Korea have the highest percentage of respondents who believe the U.S. can learn from them.

The views of Republicans and Democrats regarding Trump's conduct as president are starkly divided. Among Democrats, a significant majority of 85% express dislike for the way Trump conducts himself in office [1]. This sentiment remains consistent across ideological lines within the Democratic party, with 93% of liberal Democrats giving low marks for the ethical standards of the Trump administration [3].

In contrast, Republican views are more varied but still predominantly critical. Only 38% of Republicans say they like the way Trump conducts himself as president, while 45% have mixed feelings about his conduct, and 16% do not like it [7]. This division is further highlighted by the differences between conservative and moderate or liberal Republicans; 44% of conservative Republicans like Trump’s conduct compared to just 25% of moderate or liberal Republicans [2]. Additionally, about one-third (32%) of moderate or liberal Republicans explicitly state that they do not like his conduct in office [2].

These differing opinions are visually represented in the bar chart showing the distribution of opinions among Republicans and Democrats in May 2018 and August 2017 ![Among Republicans and Democrats, the distribution of opinions on Trump's conduct has remained consistently divided](image3). The chart illustrates that among Democrats, the percentage who dislike Trump's conduct has remained high at 88% in May 2018 and 93% in August 2017, while among Republicans, the percentages have fluctuated but still show a notable portion expressing dislike or mixed feelings.

Overall, the data indicates a clear partisan divide, with Democrats overwhelmingly disapproving of Trump's conduct and Republicans being more divided but generally less approving [7]. 

Republican and Democrat views differ significantly regarding Trump's conduct as president, with Democrats largely disapproving and Republicans showing more mixed sentiments.

Opinions on government responsibility for displaced workers show a clear divide based on political affiliation. According to the data, 65% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents believe that the government has an obligation to take care of workers displaced by automation, even if this means higher taxes for others [1]. Conversely, 68% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents feel that individuals should be responsible for their own financial well-being, even in the face of widespread job automation [1].

This stark contrast is also reflected in broader public opinion polls where the population is evenly split overall: exactly half believe the government should have an obligation to care for displaced workers, while nearly the same percentage (49%) feels individuals should be responsible for their own financial well-being [8]. 

The partisan divide is further emphasized when examining specific policies. For instance, Democrats are much more supportive than Republicans of both a universal basic income and a national service program for displaced workers [5]. This support is evident in the percentages: 77% of Democrats favor a universal income compared to just 38% of Republicans, and 66% of Democrats support a national service program versus 46% of Republicans [10].

Interestingly, despite these differences, there is more alignment between Democrats and Republicans on the issue of limiting the number of jobs businesses can replace with machines. Just over half of Republicans (54%) feel that there should be limits, which is only slightly less than the 60% of Democrats who hold this view [7]. 

To visualize these opinions, consider the breakdown shown in the bar chart `![{50% of U.S. adults believe the government has an obligation, while 49% think individuals should care for themselves.}](image5)`. This chart clearly illustrates how political affiliation influences views on government responsibility for displaced workers.

In conclusion, opinions on government responsibility for displaced workers differ significantly by political affiliation, with Democrats being more likely to support government intervention and Republicans favoring individual responsibility.

The peak hour train car requirement for Caltrain changes significantly depending on the service improvement scenarios. Currently, with a peak service level of 5x5 trains per hour, 25 train cars are required during peak hours [10]. 

If Metrolink's used cars were utilized, this would increase the peak service to 6x5, thereby raising the number of train cars needed to 30 ![{Metrolink scenario increases train cars from 25 to 30}](image5). Electrification of the trains would further enhance the peak service to 6x6, which would necessitate 36 train cars during peak hours.

Extending platforms to accommodate more cars would allow for a peak service of 6x8, thus requiring 48 train cars [5]. This is a substantial increase from the current setup and reflects a significant boost in capacity. 

In the most ambitious scenario, increasing frequency potentially with High-Speed Rail (HSR) would result in a peak service of 8x8, necessitating 64 train cars during peak hours [2]. This scenario represents the highest capacity and would dramatically improve the service compared to today’s levels ![{High-Speed Rail scenario nearly triples the number of train cars required}](image5).

Therefore, the peak hour train car requirement varies from 25 cars in the current scenario to as many as 64 cars in the increased frequency scenario with HSR.

Americans' perceptions of their country's status as the world's leading economic power have experienced notable fluctuations over time. Initially, in 2008, 46% of Americans believed the U.S. held this position [1]. This belief saw a significant rise, peaking at 59% in March 2020, but has since declined to 52% [2]. The decline is particularly evident among Democrats, with a drop from 54% in March to 44% in the current period [7].

The trend can be visualized in ![{The U.S. line starts at 46% in 2008 and fluctuates, increasing to 59% in 2020 before slightly dropping to 52%.}](image1). This graph clearly illustrates the rise and subsequent slight dip in American confidence in their country's economic dominance.

When examining differences in these perceptions between political affiliations, the data reveals a growing partisan divide. Republicans have consistently been more likely to view the U.S. as the leading economic power compared to Democrats. For instance, while Republican views have remained relatively stable, Democrats have become significantly less likely to see the U.S. as the leading global economy [7]. This shift is also reflected in ![{The "Rep/Lean Rep" group increases from 17% in 2012 to 38% in 2020, while the "Dem/Lean Dem" group increases from 11% in 2012 to 19% in 2020.}](image3), which shows the increasing gap in perception between Republicans and Democrats regarding China as an economic competitor.

In summary, Americans' perceptions of their country's status as the world's leading economic power have fluctuated, with a recent decline influenced by the coronavirus pandemic and economic forecasts. There is also a clear difference in these perceptions between political affiliations, with Republicans generally more confident than Democrats.

The number of farms in the U.S. experienced a significant decline from 1880 to 1950. Starting in 1880, there were 1,597 farms [3]. By 1900, this number peaked at 2,049 farms but then began a steady decrease. In 1910, the number dropped to 1,944 farms, followed by further reductions to 1,882 farms in 1920 and 1,766 farms in 1930. By 1950, the number of farms had fallen to 1,453 ![Number of farms decreased significantly from 1880 to 1950](image3).

This trend aligns with the observation that the scale of farming has changed dramatically due to mechanization, leading to fewer but larger farms [1]. As a result, farm operators could no longer afford to operate on small scales due to increased costs of operation.

In conclusion, the number of farms in the U.S. decreased significantly from 1880 to 1950.

In conclusion, internet and broadband usage among seniors decrease notably starting at approximately age 75.

The views on the necessity of government regulation to protect the public interest vary significantly across different political affiliations. Overall, 49% of Americans believe that government regulation is necessary to protect the public interest, while 43% think it does more harm than good [4]. 

When we break this down by political affiliation, Republicans are notably less supportive of government regulation, with only 33% believing it is necessary and 61% thinking it does more harm [4]. In contrast, a majority of Democrats (65%) see regulation as necessary, while only 29% view it as harmful [4]. This stark difference highlights the divide between these two major parties on the issue of government regulation.

Independents fall somewhat in the middle, with 48% finding regulation necessary and 43% seeing it as harmful [4]. However, when we look at Independents who lean toward either party, their views align more closely with those of the party they lean towards. For instance, among Republican-leaning independents, 33% find regulation necessary, while 58% see it as harmful [4]. Conversely, Democratic-leaning independents show strong support for regulation, with 69% viewing it as necessary and only 27% seeing it as harmful [4].

Interestingly, even among those with no clear partisan lean, opinions are divided but still lean slightly towards viewing regulation as harmful, with 31% saying it is necessary and 49% saying it does more harm [4]. 

This data is visually represented in the chart which breaks down the opinions on government regulation by political affiliation `![{Government regulation views differ significantly by political affiliation}](image4)`.

In conclusion, political affiliations differ markedly in their views on the necessity of government regulation, with Democrats being more likely to support it and Republicans more likely to oppose it.

The approval ratings for public health officials experienced a notable decline from March to August, particularly among Republicans. From 2004 to 2015, the financial expectations of Hispanics showed a more pronounced improvement compared to the general public. Initially, in 2004, about 76% of Hispanics had favorable opinions regarding their financial situation, which dipped to 67% during the Great Recession years from 2008-2010 but rebounded significantly to 81% by 2015 [2]. This trend is also visually represented in the line graph ![{Hispanic financial optimism increased from 76% in 2004 to 81% in 2015}](image2).

In contrast, the general public's financial optimism started at 70% in 2004, dropped to 56% in 2007, slightly recovered to 58% in 2010, and then rose to 61% in 2015. The bar chart further illustrates this difference, showing that while the general population's expectation for financial improvement increased by only 6 percentage points from 2008 to 2015 (from 56% to 61%), the increase among Hispanics was much larger, at 14 percentage points (from 67% to 81%) ![{The increase in financial optimism was +6 for the general population and +14 for Hispanics from 2008 to 2015}](image1).

Thus, the financial expectations of Hispanics not only surpassed those of the general public but also grew at a faster rate over the period from 2004 to 2015. 

The gap in financial expectations between Hispanics and the general public widened to 20 percentage points by 2015, with 81% of Hispanics expecting their family finances to improve compared to 61% of the general public [10].

In conclusion, the financial expectations of Hispanics improved more significantly and were consistently higher than those of the general public from 2004 to 2015.

According to the survey, many Americans believe that China's influence in world affairs will diminish following the coronavirus outbreak. Specifically, 50% of respondents think China will have less global influence after the pandemic [3]. This perception is also reflected in a bar chart showing that "Less influence" is the most selected option with a value of 50% ![{China's influence perceived to decline}](image4).

There are significant partisan divides on this issue as well. Roughly six-in-ten Republicans believe China’s international clout will diminish due to the coronavirus outbreak, while only 40% of Democrats share this view [1]. Furthermore, unfavorable views of China have increased among both Democrats and Republicans over the past two years, but Republicans express significantly more negative attitudes toward China [7].

Additionally, age plays a role in these perceptions, with older adults being more likely than younger ones to say China will have less global influence after the crisis [1]. Overall, the survey indicates a notable shift in public opinion regarding China's global stature post-pandemic.

In conclusion, many Americans perceive that China's influence in world affairs will decrease after the pandemic.

Public satisfaction with the state of the nation has experienced significant fluctuations over the period from 1990 to 2019. In 1990, 41% of the public expressed satisfaction with the way things were going in the country, while 54% were dissatisfied. Over the years, these percentages have shifted multiple times, reflecting changing national conditions and leadership.

By 2019, public satisfaction had dropped markedly; only 26% of Americans were satisfied with the state of the nation [2]. This decline is also illustrated in a line graph that tracks the trend from 1990 to 2019 ![{The "Satisfied" line starts at 41% in 1990 and decreases to 26% by 2019}](image4). The dissatisfaction rate rose from 54% in 1990 to 70% in 2019, indicating a growing discontent among the population.

During this period, partisan views diverged significantly. For instance, in September 2018, 59% of Republicans were satisfied with the state of the nation, but this figure dropped to 47% by early 2019 [8]. Similarly, Democrats' satisfaction levels have plummeted, with only 8% expressing satisfaction as of the latest data [1].

In conclusion, public satisfaction with the state of the nation has steadily declined from 1990 to 2019, reaching its lowest point in recent history.

The trend in the assembly of Net Asset Value (NAV) for European venture funds by vintage year shows a significant shift around 2005. From 1997 to 2004, both realized and unrealized portions of NAV are represented, with a noticeable decrease in the realized portion over these years while the unrealized portion remains substantial [4]. This suggests that many investments made during this period had started to be liquidated or were in the process of being realized. However, starting from 2005 to 2009, all bars are labeled as 100% unrealized, indicating that these post-bubble vintages have not yet been realized `![{Post-bubble vintages have not yet been realized}](image4)`.

This trend highlights a phase where newer funds after the financial bubble did not reach the stage of realization within the timeframe observed, possibly due to longer investment horizons or less favorable market conditions for exits during the early stages of recovery. 

In conclusion, the trend depicted is a transition from a mix of realized and unrealized NAV before 2005 to entirely unrealized NAV for post-bubble vintages.

In contrast, women are slightly more likely than men to see kind or supportive behavior on social media, although majorities of both genders report seeing an equal mix of supportive and bullying behavior [8].

Regarding the types of content encountered frequently on social media, users commonly come across posts that are overly dramatic or exaggerated, with 58% of users reporting they see this type of content frequently. Additionally, 59% of users frequently encounter people making accusations or starting arguments without waiting until they have all the facts [10].

![{Users frequently encounter exaggerated posts and unfounded accusations}](image5)

To summarize, men tend to perceive more negative behaviors such as bullying and deception on social media compared to women, while both genders frequently encounter exaggerated posts and unfounded accusations on these platforms.

The perception that news organizations had 'too much' influence on presidential elections has shown significant fluctuations over the years. According to historical data, in 1992, 46% of respondents believed the press had too much influence [image1]. This sentiment peaked at 53% in 2000 before dropping slightly to 43% in 2004 and hovering around 46% to 48% in the subsequent elections up to 2012. However, a notable shift occurred in 2016, where this percentage surged to 57%, marking the highest level of concern since 2000 [image1].

This trend aligns with the findings that about six-in-ten Trump voters (62%) felt news organizations exerted too much influence on the election outcome [5], which is consistent with the broader voter sentiment captured in the survey data. Additionally, nearly half of Clinton voters (50%) also shared this view [10], indicating a bipartisan concern regarding media influence.

The increase in perception can be contextualized by comparing it to earlier elections. For instance, after George W. Bush’s reelection in 2004, only 45% of his voters thought the press had too much influence [2]. The sharp rise in 2016 reflects a growing skepticism towards media's role in shaping electoral outcomes, as evidenced by the Pew Research Center polling [9].

![{Perception that news organizations had too much influence increased significantly in 2016}](image1)

In conclusion, the perception that news organizations had too much influence on presidential elections has generally increased over time, reaching its peak in 2016.

The trust levels in Trump's statements show a stark contrast between Republicans and Democrats. Among Republicans and Republican-leaning independents, most express greater trust in Trump compared to previous presidents. Specifically, 58% of this group say they trust what Trump says more than previous presidents, while only 15% say they trust his rhetoric less [9]. This aligns with the general positive sentiment towards Trump within the Republican base, as seen in their confidence in his success as a president [1].

On the other hand, almost all Democrats and Democratic leaners (94%) say they trust what Trump says less than they trusted what previous presidents said while in office [7]. This significant disparity is further highlighted by the broader public opinion, where 58% of people overall trust Trump's statements less than those of previous presidents [8].

![{Republicans are more likely to trust Trump more than previous presidents, while Democrats overwhelmingly trust him less}](image5)

In conclusion, Republicans generally trust Trump's statements more than those of previous presidents, whereas Democrats predominantly trust him less.

Based on the provided data, let's analyze the smartphone ownership among the respondents. According to the infographic depicted in ![{72% of respondents own a mobile phone and 38% of those who own a mobile phone have a smartphone}](image3), we can calculate the percentage of respondents who own a smartphone.

From the text, we know that the survey included 4,021 respondents [9]. Among these respondents, 72% own a mobile phone, and out of these mobile phone owners, 38% have a smartphone. To find the overall percentage of respondents who own a smartphone, we multiply these two percentages:

\[ 72\% \times 38\% = 0.72 \times 0.38 = 0.2736 \]

Converting this to a percentage gives us approximately 27.36%.

Therefore, among the 4,021 respondents, about 27.36% own a smartphone.

From October 2017 to January 2019, the perception of Trump's economic policies significantly shifted among both Republicans and Democrats. Among Republicans, there was a notable increase in positive views. In October 2017, 63% of Republicans believed that Trump's policies had made economic conditions better [4]. By January 2019, this figure surged to 79%, indicating a substantial rise in optimism regarding Trump's economic impact ![{Republicans' optimism about Trump's economic policies increased from 63% to 79%}](image4).

Conversely, Democrats became more pessimistic over the same period. In October 2017, only 6% of Democrats thought Trump's policies had improved economic conditions, while 64% felt they had not had much effect [4]. However, by January 2019, the percentage of Democrats who believed Trump's policies made things worse rose sharply to 46%, and those who felt there was no significant effect dropped to 41% ![{Democrats' pessimism about Trump's economic policies increased with 46% feeling conditions worsened}](image4).

In summary, Republicans became more optimistic about Trump's economic policies, while Democrats grew more negative.

The overall energy efficiency from source to wheel for electric vehicles (EVs) and internal combustion engine vehicles (ICEVs) can be compared using detailed data on the efficiencies at various stages of energy conversion. For EVs, the process starts with generation, where the efficiency is 33%, followed by transmission with 94% efficiency, resulting in a well-to-tank efficiency of 31%. The plug-to-wheels efficiency is 76%, leading to an overall efficiency of 23% from source to wheel [4]. 

On the other hand, for ICEVs, the refining stage has an efficiency of 82%, and the transmission (transport of fuel) stage is 98%, giving a well-to-tank efficiency of 80%. However, the pump-to-wheels efficiency is only 16%, resulting in an overall efficiency from source to wheel of just 13% [4].

![{Electric vehicles are more energy-efficient compared to internal combustion engine vehicles when considering the entire energy conversion chain from well-to-wheel.}](image4)

In conclusion, electric vehicles have a higher overall energy efficiency from source to wheel compared to internal combustion engine vehicles.

Physical health conditions significantly impact technology use among older adults more than they do for the general adult population. According to the data, 23% of adults aged 65 and older report having a physical or health condition that makes reading difficult or challenging, compared to only 16% of all adults [7]. Similarly, 29% of older adults have a disability, handicap, or chronic disease that prevents them from fully participating in many common daily activities, while this percentage is lower at 18% for all adults ![Physical challenges are more prevalent among seniors](image1).

These physical challenges contribute to lower rates of technology adoption among older adults. For instance, only 49% of seniors with these physical challenges go online, compared to 66% of those without such challenges [3]. Additionally, seniors facing these issues are less likely to own devices like cell phones (69% vs. 82%) or have broadband at home (38% vs. 53%) [3].

Furthermore, the data from another source highlights that the adoption of smartphones and cell phones varies greatly based on age, education, and income within the older adult population. For example, only 5% of those aged 80 and older own a smartphone, whereas 29% of those aged 65-69 do [2]. This disparity underscores how physical health conditions can compound other factors like age and socioeconomic status to further limit technology use among older adults ![Technology ownership varies by age and education](image2).

In conclusion, physical health conditions affect technology use more profoundly among older adults compared to all adults, leading to lower rates of internet usage and device ownership.

According to the data, 49% of Americans cite not enough timely testing as a major reason for the continuation of the COVID-19 outbreak [8]. According to the Pew Research Center survey, the most cited major reason for the continuation of the COVID-19 outbreak is that not enough people are following social distancing and mask-wearing guidelines. This sentiment is echoed in multiple sources, with three-quarters of Americans identifying this as a major factor [2]. The data from the bar chart also supports this, showing that 75% of respondents consider insufficient adherence to social distancing and mask-wearing as a major reason for the continued spread ![{75% consider it a major reason}](image1).

Additionally, the partisan gap on this issue is evident but less pronounced compared to other factors. While a narrower majority of Republicans (57%) view this as a major reason, an overwhelming majority of Democrats (89%) agree with this assessment [4]. 

In conclusion, the most cited major reason for the continuation of the COVID-19 outbreak is that not enough people are following social distancing and mask-wearing guidelines.

From 2020 to 2021, the issues related to China that showed significant increases in concern among Americans include cyber attacks from China, China’s policies on human rights, and the loss of U.S. jobs to China [4]. Specifically, the percentage of Americans who consider cyber attacks from China a very serious problem increased by 7 percentage points, rising from 58% in 2020 to 65% in 2021 ![{Cyberattacks concern rose significantly}](image4).

Similarly, concern over China’s policies on human rights also saw a notable increase of 7 percentage points, with 50% of Americans now viewing it as a very serious problem compared to 43% in 2020 [9]. Additionally, the issue of job losses to China became more pressing, with a 6 percentage point rise, reaching 53% in 2021 [4].

These increases reflect growing anxieties about China's actions and policies, particularly in areas that directly impact national security and economic stability.

The greatest increase in concern was seen in cyber attacks from China, which saw a 7 percentage point rise in perception as a very serious problem from 2020 to 2021.

The frequency of attending Hispanic cultural celebrations in childhood indeed varies significantly across different immigrant generations. Among self-identified Hispanics who are foreign-born, a substantial majority report that their parents took them to these celebrations often [7]. This is reflected in the data showing that 59% of foreign-born Hispanics attended such events frequently during their childhood ![{Foreign-born Hispanics have the highest attendance at cultural celebrations}](image4).

For second-generation Hispanics, the trend continues but with a slight decrease; about half (49%) say they often attended Hispanic cultural celebrations when growing up [7]. This aligns with the findings that second-generation individuals still maintain strong ties to their cultural heritage but experience it less frequently than the first generation ![{Second-generation Hispanics attend cultural celebrations less frequently than the first generation}](image4).

By the third or higher generations, there is a notable drop in the frequency of attending these celebrations. Only 35% of third or higher generation self-identified Hispanics report often going to such events during their childhood [7]. Additionally, this group shows a significant shift where 60% of non-Hispanics with Hispanic ancestry say they never attended these celebrations [8], indicating a clear decline in participation as the distance from the immigrant experience increases.

In conclusion, the frequency of attending Hispanic cultural celebrations decreases across successive immigrant generations, with the most noticeable decline occurring by the third or higher generation.

Women's representation in STEM jobs varies significantly by education level compared to the overall employed population. According to the data, women with higher levels of education are more likely to be represented in STEM jobs. For instance, among those with a professional or doctoral degree, 41% are women in STEM jobs [9]. This contrasts with the overall employed population where the percentage of women is slightly lower at 42% for the same educational level ![Professional/doctoral degree: 41% in STEM vs 42% in all employed](image3).

Furthermore, the trend shows that as educational attainment increases, so does the proportion of women in STEM jobs. From 1990 to 2016, the percentage of women in STEM jobs has increased across all educational levels. Notably, the most significant gains have been observed among women with advanced degrees. For example, the percentage of women with a master's degree in STEM jobs grew from 37% in 1990 to 47% in 2016 ![{Growth in women's representation in STEM jobs by education level}](image5).

In contrast, for those with a high school education or less, the increase in women's representation in STEM jobs was minimal, rising from 52% in 1990 to 55% in 2016. Similarly, for those with some college education, the representation increased from 56% in 1990 to 59% in 2016. These figures suggest that higher education plays a crucial role in increasing women's participation in STEM fields.

Overall, women's representation in STEM jobs tends to be higher among those with advanced degrees compared to the overall employed population.

Female representation varies significantly across different STEM job clusters. For instance, women are overrepresented in health-related jobs, making up three-quarters (75%) of healthcare practitioners and technicians [3]. This is further illustrated by the dot plot showing that health-related jobs have a higher share of women, with most data points between 70% and 100% ![{Health-related jobs have a higher share of women}](image3).

In contrast, women are underrepresented in engineering jobs, comprising only 14% of workers in this field [8]. The same dot plot highlights that engineering jobs have one of the lowest female representations, with an average of 14% ![{Engineering jobs have the lowest female representation}](image3).

Computer occupations also show lower female participation, with women making up just 25% of workers in these fields [6]. The bar chart comparing men and women in computer jobs underscores this disparity, revealing significant gender differences in experiences such as gender-related discrimination and sexual harassment [5] ![{Women face more gender-related challenges in computer jobs}](image5).

Life science jobs and math jobs have a more balanced representation, with women comprising approximately 47% and 46% respectively [8]. Physical science jobs, however, still see underrepresentation with women accounting for about 39% of workers [8].

Overall, while women make up half (50%) of all U.S. workers in STEM occupations, their presence varies widely across occupational clusters [4], reflecting both progress and persistent disparities in certain fields. 

In conclusion, female representation varies widely across different STEM job clusters, with notable overrepresentation in health-related jobs and underrepresentation in engineering and computer jobs.

The demographic group that showed the largest increase in financial optimism from 2008 to 2015 is Latinos, specifically those who had completed some college. According to the data, economic optimism among Latinos with some college education increased by 20 percentage points [6]. This significant rise can also be visualized in the bar chart comparing different demographic subgroups, where the "Some college or more" category for Latinos shows a substantial increase from 65% in 2008 to 85% in 2015, a difference of +20 ![{Latinos with some college education show a significant increase in financial optimism}](image2).

In contrast, the general public's optimism about their family’s future economic prospects rose by only 6 percentage points during the same period [2], as illustrated in the bar chart comparing the general population and all Hispanics, where the general population's increase was from 56% in 2008 to 61% in 2015 ![{General population's optimism increased less compared to Hispanics}](image1).

Therefore, the Latinos who had completed some college showed the largest increase in financial optimism from 2008 to 2015.

The unfavorable opinion of China has significantly increased across all age groups from 2005 to 2020, as illustrated in the trends shown by the line graph ![{All age groups show an upward trend in unfavorable opinions from 2005 to 2020}](image2). Furthermore, the increase in negative perceptions among older Americans aligns with their greater likelihood to see China as an enemy compared to younger counterparts [2].

Therefore, the unfavorable opinion of China has notably intensified across all age groups, with the most pronounced change occurring among those aged 50 and older.

The population of Hamilton County underwent significant changes from 1870 to 2000. Initially, the county's population was quite small, with only 130 residents in 1870 [3]. However, this number grew dramatically over the following decades. By 1880, the population had surged to 8,267, and it reached its peak in 1890 at 14,096 [3]. This rapid growth coincided with the establishment of numerous rural school districts and the development of farming communities [2].

After reaching its peak in 1890, the population began a slow decline. According to the census data, by 1900 the population had decreased slightly to 13,330, and continued to fluctuate over the next several decades [3]. The table showing population data for various census years illustrates this trend ![Population trends over time](image3).

Despite overall declines, some towns within Hamilton County experienced periods of growth. For instance, Aurora saw a steady increase in population since 1940, peaking at 4,225 in 2000 [4]. On the other hand, smaller towns like Hordville and Polk have struggled to maintain their populations due to their dependence on the surrounding farming community [5].

In summary, the population of Hamilton County increased sharply from 1870 to 1890, then gradually declined until 2000, with some fluctuations and localized growth in certain areas.

The support for automatically registering all eligible citizens to vote differs significantly between Democrats and Republicans. Over time, the views of Republicans have shifted towards less support for this policy. Since 2018, there has been a decline in the share of Republicans who support automatic voter registration from 49% to 38% [6]. In contrast, Democrats have shown consistent and strong support for this measure, with 82% of Democrats favoring automatic registration as of the latest survey [2].

![{Support for automatic voter registration has decreased among Republicans while remaining high among Democrats}](image3)

This trend is also reflected in broader surveys where the overall public support for automatic registration has slightly decreased from 65% in 2018 to 61% in recent years, driven primarily by the declining support from Republicans [9]. Meanwhile, Democrats' support has ticked up slightly from 78% in 2018 to 82% today [6]. The partisan divide on this issue is clear, with Democrats being far more supportive of automatically registering all eligible citizens to vote compared to Republicans.

In summary, Democrats are far more supportive of automatically registering all eligible citizens to vote compared to Republicans.

The experiences of discrimination and perceptions of fairness in STEM jobs significantly differ between racial/ethnic groups, particularly for blacks compared to whites. According to the data, a substantial disparity exists in how these groups perceive and experience workplace dynamics [4]. 

For instance, 62% of black STEM workers report experiencing discrimination at work because of their race or ethnicity, which is markedly higher than the 13% reported by white STEM workers ![{62% of black respondents reported experiencing discrimination, indicating a significantly higher experience of workplace discrimination compared to other groups}](image4). This highlights a significant difference in the prevalence of discrimination faced by black workers compared to their white counterparts.

Moreover, when it comes to the impact of race or ethnicity on career success, 40% of black STEM workers believe it has been harder for them to find success due to their race or ethnicity, while only 5% of white STEM workers share this view [2]. This underscores the belief among black workers that their race poses a barrier to professional advancement.

Regarding perceptions of workplace attention to diversity, 57% of black STEM workers feel that their workplace does not pay enough attention to increasing diversity, whereas only 15% of white STEM workers hold this opinion ![{57% of Black respondents feel their workplace pays insufficient attention to diversity issues}](image4). This indicates a notable gap in the perception of workplace efforts towards inclusivity.

In terms of fair treatment during recruitment and hiring processes, 43% of black STEM workers believe that blacks are usually treated fairly, while 78% of white STEM workers think the process is fair [3]. Similarly, for promotion and advancement opportunities, 37% of black STEM workers believe they are fair, compared to 75% of white STEM workers [3].

In summary, black STEM workers are more likely to experience discrimination and perceive less fairness in hiring and promotion processes compared to white STEM workers.

Pre-training significantly affects BLEU scores for different language pairs, especially when the baseline system is moderately effective but not too poor. For instance, in higher-resource languages, pre-training consistently increases BLEU scores by approximately 3 points for all three language pairs [1]. However, for extremely low-resource languages, the impact varies: some languages like Galician (GL) experience a substantial gain of up to 11 BLEU points, while others like Azerbaijani (AZ) and Belarusian (BE) show smaller gains [1].

The effectiveness of pre-training is also influenced by the size of the training data. As illustrated in the graphs ![{pre-training benefits diminish with larger datasets}](image2), pre-training yields more significant improvements when the training set is small. For example, Portuguese (PT) to English (EN) translations benefit less from pre-training as the dataset size increases, whereas the gains are more pronounced for smaller datasets.

Moreover, qualitative analysis of GL→EN translations reveals that pre-training helps capture rarer vocabulary and generates more grammatically well-formed sentences [2]. This is evident in the successful translation of specific terms such as "chris," "big lawyer," and "patent legislation" [2]. 

Additionally, aligning word embeddings can further enhance performance. The table comparing aligned and unaligned scores ![{alignment generally decreases or slightly increases BLEU scores}](image1) shows that for GL→EN, alignment slightly reduces the BLEU score, while for RU→EN, it provides a small increase. 

In multilingual translation systems, pre-training can leverage shared encoders or decoders between multiple languages to improve BLEU scores [5]. Notably, the similarity between source languages plays a crucial role. For example, GL/PT, which are closely related, exhibit the largest gains from pre-training [10].

Overall, pre-training generally boosts BLEU scores, particularly for low-resource languages and smaller datasets, and when the baseline system is moderately effective.

The inclusion of reference translations significantly improves the COMET-RANK metric scores for language pairs involving English. This improvement is quantified in a table that compares COMET-RANK scores with and without references [2]. Specifically, the Δτ values, which represent the difference in Kendall’s Tau correlation when using only references versus using both source and reference translations, are provided for several language pairs.

For example, when evaluating translations from English to other languages (en-cs, en-de, en-fi, en-tr), the improvements in Δτ are modest but noticeable: 0.051 for en-cs, 0.035 for en-de, 0.041 for en-fi, and 0.024 for en-tr. However, the most substantial improvements occur in reverse language pairs, where English is the target language (cs-en, de-en, fi-en, tr-en). The Δτ values for these pairs are much higher: 0.107 for cs-en, 0.155 for de-en, 0.119 for fi-en, and 0.132 for tr-en ![The inclusion of references significantly boosts COMET-RANK scores especially for translations into English](image2).

This pattern suggests that the inclusion of references has a more pronounced effect on improving the COMET-RANK metric when English is the target language compared to when it is the source language. This observation aligns with the hypothesis that leveraging both source and reference texts enhances the model's ability to make accurate predictions, particularly when English is involved as a target language [9].

In conclusion, the inclusion of reference translations notably enhances the performance of the COMET-RANK metric, with the most significant improvements observed in translations into English.
